componenttextpreview: Good day, and welcome to the Philip Morris International Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I will now turn the call over to Mr. Nick Rolli, Vice President of Investor Relations and Financial Communications. Please go ahe
componenttext: Good day, and welcome to the Philip Morris International Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I will now turn the call over to Mr. Nick Rolli, Vice President of Investor Relations and Financial Communications. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Welcome. Thank you for joining us. Earlier today, we issued a news release containing detailed information on our 2010 third quarter results. You may access the release on our website at www.pmi.com.During our call today, we'll be talking about results
componenttext:
Welcome. Thank you for joining us. Earlier today, we issued a news release containing detailed information on our 2010 third quarter results. You may access the release on our website at www.pmi.com.
During our call today, we'll be talking about results in the third quarter of 2010 and comparing them with the same period in 2009, unless otherwise stated. References to volumes are for PMI shipments. Industry volume and market shares are the latest data available from a number of internal and external sources. Net revenue data excludes excise taxes. Acquisitions, for the purposes of this presentation, also include our business combination with Fortune Tobacco Corporation in the Philippines. Organic volume refers to volume excluding acquisitions.
You'll find data tables showing how we made adjustments to net revenues and operating companies income, or OCI, for currency, acquisitions, asset impairment, exit and other costs, free cash flow calculations and adjustments to earnings per share or EPS, as well as reconciliations to U.S. GAAP measures at the end of today's webcast slides, which are posted on our website.
Today's remarks contain forward-looking statements and projections of future results, and I direct your attention to the forward-looking and cautionary statements disclosure in today's presentation and news release for a review of the various factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from projections. It is now my pleasure to introduce Hermann Waldemer, Chief Financial Officer. Hermann?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Nick, and welcome, ladies and gentlemen. As anticipated, our third quarter results were adversely impacted by various timing issues, in particular, relating to Japan. More than half of our organic volume decline in the quarter was attributable
componenttext:
Thank you, Nick, and welcome, ladies and gentlemen. As anticipated, our third quarter results were adversely impacted by various timing issues, in particular, relating to Japan. More than half of our organic volume decline in the quarter was attributable to the payback for the previously disclosed 3.4 billion unit build up of stocks at our distributor in Japan during the second quarter this year. The lower sales to Japan also drove an unfavorable geographic mix in the quarter. We do, however, remain very competitive in this important market. The Marlboro is growing share behind innovative plan extensions such as Marlboro Black Menthol and Marlboro Ice Blast, which reached the combined market share of 2% in the quarter. 
We continue to face a difficult environment in both Greece and Turkey, resulting from the significant tax increases that occurred earlier this year. Industry volume in these markets was down by 8% and 6% respectively in the third quarter. And dividing of price [ph] has led to consumer down trading and an unfavorable product mix. 
These three issues masked and underwrites strong underlying business performance. I would like to mention in particular the good results of Marlboro, driven by the new architecture and innovative line extensions. The market share of Marlboro was higher or stable in the third quarter across all four of our regions. 
A notable highlight of the quarter was our continued strong cash flow performance, with operating cash flow increasing by more than 30% in the quarter. This allowed us to accelerate the implementation of our share repurchase program and to increase our dividend by 10.3% in September.
Indeed, the strength of our underlying business along with more favorable exchange rates and the lower tax rate has led us to raise and narrow our reported diluted EPS guidance for 2010 to a range of $3.90 to $3.95. This represents our reported diluted EPS growth rate of approximately 20% to 22% compared to the $3.24 achieved last year. Excluding currency, the growth rate in our guidance is now approximately 16% to 18% compared to 14% to 17%, projected previously.
Our cigarette volume in the quarter increased by 4.5% to 229.2 billion units, driven by a successful business combination with Fortune Tobacco in the Philippines. Excluding acquisitions, our volume declines by 2.9% or 6.3 billion units. In addition to Japan, Ukraine contributed 2.6 billion units to this decline, reflecting both the timing of shipments and market contraction, following a series of tax-driven price increases. Our volume was also unfavorably influenced by lower industry volumes in such markets as Greece, Poland, Spain and Turkey. 
On a year-to-date basis, our organic volume was down by 1.6% or 10.5 billion units. The decline was driven in particular by Turkey and Ukraine, whose combined volume was down 10.1 billion units, as well as by Greece and Spain. Our volume in number of important emerging markets, including Algeria, Argentina, Egypt, Indonesia, Korea, Mexico and Russia has, however, increased this year. 
Our net revenues, excluding currency and acquisitions were down slightly in the quarter, impacted in particular by the timing of shipments to Japan, the need to partially absorb Texas and lower volumes in Greece, lower volumes and an unfavorable mix in Turkey and the netting [ph] of last year's price increase in Germany.  On a year-to-date basis, our net revenues, excluding currency and acquisitions, are up 3.6%. 
Our OCI in the third quarter was unfavorably impacted by two timing effects and difficult comparisons, namely, the aforementioned timing of Japanese shipments and pricing, as well as the tax-driven industry volume declines and unfavorable mix in Greece and Turkey and lower industry volumes in Spain and Ukraine. 
During the third quarter last year, we achieved a record pricing variance of $590 million. Our pricing variance in the third quarter this year was $292 million, as we notably lapped price increases in Germany and Turkey and were obliged to partially absorb higher taxes in Greece. Consequently, we were not able to fully offset the lower volume and unfavorable geographic mix in this quarter and adjusted OCI declined by 1.7%, excluding currency and acquisition, while adjusted diluted EPS grew at a slower rate of 5.4% excluding currency. 
On a year-to-date basis, adjusted OCI increased by 4.5%, excluding currency and acquisitions. These results were impacted by lower volumes, the skew of our pricing variance this year towards the fourth quarter and higher costs, which we were able to partially offset throughout productivity program. 
As previously disclosed, tobacco leaf prices increases are expected to have an impact of around $215 million for the full year 2010. In addition, we have increased our investments in marketing, sales, R&D and infrastructure. Going forward, we expect tobacco leaf prices increases to be broadly in line with inflation, and we will continue our rigorous focus on cost controls and productivity gains.  
Our adjusted diluted EPS for this year was 12.5%, excluding currency. The underlying strength of our business and favorable pricing prospects are the basis for our confidence in our full year guidance. 
We expect to reap the benefits in the fourth quarter of recently implemented price increases in Argentina, Indonesia, Italy, Japan, Russia and the U.K. In addition, we have announced a price increase of EUR 0.30 across our portfolio in France, higher prices as of next month in Poland and have filed for a price increase with the customs authorities in Portugal. 
Furthermore, we build benefits substantially in the fourth quarter from the revaluation of the inventories at our distributor in Japan. This represents the increased margin on our future sales to the trade, but from an accounting perspective, was taken in October in one go due to our import structure in this market. We therefore expect our pricing variance in the fourth quarter this year to be significantly higher than in the third quarter. 
Our underlying business performed strongly in the third quarter with share gain for the company and for Marlboro in the EU region and good share momentum across all regions. PMI achieved year-on-year or sequential share growth notably in Nigeria, Argentina, Egypt, Greece, Indonesia, Korea, Mexico, The Netherlands, Poland, Russia, Serbia, Spain and Turkey.
A key driver of our improved business momentum has been the successful rollout of the new Marlboro architecture. In the third quarter, the share of Marlboro increased, almost stable, in all four of our regions. The market share of Marlboro in the EU region grew by over two points in the third quarter to 18.4%. The solid performance is notably in Belgium, Italy, The Netherlands, Poland and Spain. In the highly price-sensitive German market, Marlboro's recovery is being hampered by a revenue of price gaps. In Greece, consumers have been down-trading due to steep price increases and in large price gaps in a difficult economic environments.
L&M is the second best selling cigarette brand in the EU region after Marlboro. It's strong momentum continued in the third quarter. There's market share growth notably in Belgium, Czech Republic, Germany, Greece, The Netherlands, Poland, Portugal and Slovakia. For the region as a whole, L&M grew 0.6 share points to 6.3%. 
Outside the EU region, Marlboro is performing very strongly, with market share gains across a wide range of different geographies. Marlboro volume increased by 9.8% in Asia, excluding Japan, was up 0.8% in the Latin America and Canada region and was down only marginally in the region. 
Let me now turn to our momentum in key markets, starting with the EU region. In the third quarter, total industry volume was down 5.5%, driven primarily by the recession-related, double-digit decline of the Spanish market. The combination of price elasticity this year and trade purchase patents last year in the Polish market and the impact of higher prices and the economic crisis in Greece. Our total market share in the EU region increased by 0.2 points in the third quarter to 39.1% behind an overall solid performance across our main markets. 
In Greece, our market share is increasing sequentially as the growth of L&M has more than offset the decline in Marlboro. To maintain the competitiveness of Marlboro, we were obliged to partially absorb tax increases that occurred earlier this year. We expect that the Greek markets will continue to act as a drag on our regional profitability growth into the beginning of next year while discussions on structural changes to the excise tax system continue.
We increased our shipment volume in the very important Russian market by 1.4% in the third quarter to a record level of 25.4 billion units. The strong performance was driven by above premium parliament, mid-priced Chesterfield and low-priced Bond Street and mixed. PMI implemented price increases of two to three rubles per pack in July. The market is stabilizing overall and consumer down-trading continues to slow. 
Industry volumes during the third quarter in Ukraine is estimated to have been down about 15%, reflecting the size of trade purchases in June, ahead of the latest tax increases, and a market contraction, resulting from continuous price increases over the last two years. Our volume declined by 2.6 billion units or about one quarter. Premium Marlboro and mid-priced Chesterfield gain share, but we shed share at the low end of the markets. The improved mix and higher prices enabled us to strongly increase our profitability in Ukraine during the third quarter.
While the decline slowed in the third quarter, industry volume in Turkey was still down by about 6% year-over-year. As consumers have switched to contraband cigarettes and loose tobacco, following the very large tax-driven price increases earlier this year. Though our volume and product mix remains unfavorable compared to last year, our market share in Turkey is starting to improve sequentially, which makes us optimistic that the outlook will be better next year after a difficult 2010. 
While our shipments to Japan in the third quarter were 3.5 billion units below the prior year, sales by our distributor to the trade rose by 4 billion units or 27.3%. We estimate that the retail trade build up about 10 days of additional stock and consumers purchased some three weeks of stock ahead of the October, 2010 retail price increases. Consequently, retail sales this month have been very limited, and we will only be able to see the consumers' reaction to the higher prices towards the end of the quarter and during the first part of next year. 
Let me remind you that the retails and implants for cigarettes grew very significantly this month with a 37.5 increase for Marlboro. While the price increases are unprecedented in their magnitude and take place in a deflationary environment, cigarettes remain relatively affordable, and therefore, we are optimistic that our profitability will be enhanced going forward. 
Industry volume in Indonesia grew by a further 3.9% in the quarter, broadly in line with the annual trends. Our shipments were up 3.1% in the third quarter despite the temporarily unfavorable impact on A Mild, as the leading brand in Indonesia of costing through the 10,000 rupiah per pack price point. Our overall market share was down 0.2 points, while our profitability in Indonesia grew at a double-digit rate in the quarter, thanks to higher prices and the current volumes.
In Korea, PMI volume increased by 9.7% in the third quarter and our market share grew by 2.4 points to 17%, thanks in particular to Marlboro and Parliament, whose growth in recent quarters in Korea has been nothing less than spectacular. Meanwhile, as sales fair in the world [ph], PMI continues to have looked at the adoption of a system of regular, moderate excise tax increases. 
In the Latin America and Canada region, overall industry volume in key markets was essentially stable in the quarter. The Canadian market grew by 4.2% a slower pace that reflects the fact that we have left the period last year, when the provincial authorities in Québec and Ontario started to increase their enforcement against contraband sales. The markets in Argentina and Mexico were down slightly. Our strong growth, share growth, continued in the quarter in the key markets of Argentina and Mexico. In the latter, Marlboro continued to grow share and has now captured nearly half the market, helped by the rollout of the new architecture. 
Excluding currency and acquisitions, OCI in the quarter was up 2.2%, driven by higher pricing that was partially offset by lower volumes and an unfavorable mix in Canada. The low-priced brands have become more prominent, following the decline in the elicit trade. In the fourth quarter, profitability will be enhanced by the recently announced retail price increase of peso in Argentina. 
Our working capital reduction program is reinforcing our tremendous cash flow generation. In the third quarter this year, our operating cash flow was 30.9% higher at $2.4 billion. Excluding currency, operating cash flow was up by 43.6%. Free cash flow increased at a slightly faster rate or 33.6% and 47.4%, excluding currency. 
On a year-to-date basis, our operating cash flow has reached $7.9 billion for a cumulative total of $23.7 billion since the beginning of 2008. With one quarter to go, we have already surpassed the $27 billion cumulative three-year operating cash flow target that we established at the spin by nearly 10%.
Our financial strength enables us to generously reward our shareholders. Thanks to the continued strong growth of our cash flow, we have increased our allocations for share repurchases for the full year to $5 billion, accelerating the rate of purchases this year under our previously approved program by $1 billion more than originally foreseen. 
In the third quarter we spent $1.1 billion to purchase an additional 20.7 million shares and has spent $3.9 billion in all so far this year to buy 78.5 million shares.  In September, we increased our quarterly dividend by 10.3% to $0.64 a share, an annualized rate of $2.56. In fact, since the March 2008 spin, we have raised our dividend by 39% and our dividend yield stands at 4.5%.
So let me now summarize. By the belief, we continue to be an attractive investment opportunity. We have strong business momentum going into the fourth quarter, and we'll benefit from higher margins to Japan as well as price increases in Argentina, France, Indonesia, Italy, Poland, Portugal, Russia and the UK. We also have a more favorable currency tailwind and previously factored into our forecast and a lower tax rate. 
Consequently, we are raising in net earnings. Our reported diluted EPS guidance for 2010 to a range of $3.90 to $3.95. Compared to 2009, this represents a strong growth rate of approximately 20% to 22%. 
We have market leadership and are growing volume and overall share in emerging markets. Marlboro is performing well behind its new brand architecture and innovative plan extensions, with overall share up in EU regions in the third quarter and either increasing or stable in our three other regions. 
Our pricing power remains strong due to our brand leadership and broad portfolio. The outlook for costs going forward is improving. Our growing cash flow has enabled us to accelerate our share repurchase program this year to a total spending target of $5 billion. And we raised our dividend by 10.3% in September, thus providing effective returns to our shareholders. Thank you. I will now be pleased to answer any questions you may have.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is coming from David Adelman with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is coming from David Adelman with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: First, with respect to pricing in the quarter, you highlighted a number of comparative issues, timing issues. You talked about the fourth quarter. But if you step back, do you feel as if there's been any moderation in your broad global capacity to raise p
componenttext: First, with respect to pricing in the quarter, you highlighted a number of comparative issues, timing issues. You talked about the fourth quarter. But if you step back, do you feel as if there's been any moderation in your broad global capacity to raise pricing either because of consumer resistance or competitive dynamics?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, I don't see a moderation there. We continue to do what we did last year and the year before. We look at every market. We take our decisions on a market-by-market basis. As you know, underlying fundamentals that would've changed.
componenttext: No, I don't see a moderation there. We continue to do what we did last year and the year before. We look at every market. We take our decisions on a market-by-market basis. As you know, underlying fundamentals that would've changed.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And secondly, Hermann, I know you're not going to discreetly comment about the outlook for next year, but would you agree there are a number of dynamics that should flatter results next year. You're going to have significant pricing in Japan, where presum
componenttext: And secondly, Hermann, I know you're not going to discreetly comment about the outlook for next year, but would you agree there are a number of dynamics that should flatter results next year. You're going to have significant pricing in Japan, where presumably profits, prior to this increase, have been on a downward trend. You have FX in your favor. You're seeing some improvements in the EM, in emerging markets. You're going to get some cost savings in the Philippines and the buyback will continue. Do you agree with those sort of -- not that there won't be negative dynamics next year, but you certainly will go into next year with those things in your favor.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, absolutely. I don't know about Forex because nobody knows about foreign exchange the way it looks now today. Yes, Japan, of course, we have tremendous margin increases in there. We all know that we have to see what the consumer reaction is. Yes, we d
componenttext: Yes, absolutely. I don't know about Forex because nobody knows about foreign exchange the way it looks now today. Yes, Japan, of course, we have tremendous margin increases in there. We all know that we have to see what the consumer reaction is. Yes, we do have a very strong position in emerging markets further reinforced of course by the business combination in the Philippines, and beyond that, of course fantastic position there. Yes, there are certainly cost synergies as well that you can find there. Overall, I would also say that we will certainly keep our cost focus and productivity focus also in the next year.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Lastly, in Japan, am I right thinking that this one-off windfall from the re-evaluation of inventory maybe that's $100 million or $120 million?
componenttext: Lastly, in Japan, am I right thinking that this one-off windfall from the re-evaluation of inventory maybe that's $100 million or $120 million?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Might be even slightly better than that.
componenttext: Might be even slightly better than that.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Although that's truly one off, correct? I mean, that's sort of a windfall. You'll be less that next year, when you look at the fourth quarter?
componenttext: Although that's truly one off, correct? I mean, that's sort of a windfall. You'll be less that next year, when you look at the fourth quarter?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, that's not a windfall. Really what it is there, this reflects the increased margins on our products. In a different situation, a different structure in the market, you won't realize those additional market margins simply as you sell your products now
componenttext: No, that's not a windfall. Really what it is there, this reflects the increased margins on our products. In a different situation, a different structure in the market, you won't realize those additional market margins simply as you sell your products now to the consumer. We have an import structure in the Japanese market, which only means that on the inventories at the distributor, you take this margin increase in one go already in the month of October, which otherwise would've come in kind of every day. So it's not at all a windfall. It is simply reflecting the increased margins in that market, going forward.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our Next question comes from Judy Hong of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our Next question comes from Judy Hong of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: On Japan, so all of the inventory that got built up in the second quarter, would you say that, that has been now kind of flushed out at the shipment level now, so that in fourth quarter, it would really be a reflection of what the consumer dynamic would l
componenttext: On Japan, so all of the inventory that got built up in the second quarter, would you say that, that has been now kind of flushed out at the shipment level now, so that in fourth quarter, it would really be a reflection of what the consumer dynamic would look like?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, we have inventories in the market that's kind of on the basis of middle of the road assumption we considered to be unreasonable. Now of course, we will see what's the real consumer reaction here, and you always have to adopt their inventories
componenttext: Yes. I mean, we have inventories in the market that's kind of on the basis of middle of the road assumption we considered to be unreasonable. Now of course, we will see what's the real consumer reaction here, and you always have to adopt their inventories to your prospective sales. But I believe that you're on a very reasonable basis their, which is baked in into our full year guidance.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just staying on Japan, in terms of -- going back to David's question. So you have the margin improvement from the higher pricing that you've taken, but you also have the favorable revaluation of I think, about $32 million that should benefit you in the fo
componenttext: Just staying on Japan, in terms of -- going back to David's question. So you have the margin improvement from the higher pricing that you've taken, but you also have the favorable revaluation of I think, about $32 million that should benefit you in the fourth quarter?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: No. The secret in Japan has simply been that if I go quarter by quarter, you have the inventory buildup in the second. You have to pay back for that in the third. There is no tax windfall in the market in Japan that is taken by the government. Every produ
componenttext: No. The secret in Japan has simply been that if I go quarter by quarter, you have the inventory buildup in the second. You have to pay back for that in the third. There is no tax windfall in the market in Japan that is taken by the government. Every product sold as of October 1, the new tax has to be paid and gets to the government. So what's coming in now is really the additional margin on the stock at the distributor which we have. That additional margin that is made on the inventories at the retailer stays with the retailer. That's the only thing there.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just kind of taking a step back and looking at your operating profit in the third quarter. Obviously, a lot of negative impact from Japan and so forth. But if you adjust for Japan and the tax absorption in Greece, are you able to quantify how much adjuste
componenttext: Just kind of taking a step back and looking at your operating profit in the third quarter. Obviously, a lot of negative impact from Japan and so forth. But if you adjust for Japan and the tax absorption in Greece, are you able to quantify how much adjusted operating income ex currency and ex acquisition would have been in the third quarter?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: There's two ways of looking at that. I mean, the first one, adjusted growth rates. So, let's put it this way. Japan alone is about a four percentage points drag in PMI's results in the quarter, and Greece and Turkey together would add another two percenta
componenttext: There's two ways of looking at that. I mean, the first one, adjusted growth rates. So, let's put it this way. Japan alone is about a four percentage points drag in PMI's results in the quarter, and Greece and Turkey together would add another two percentage points. But actually, maybe an even better way to answer your question is really to look at OCI margins, because in the third quarter, the overall PMI ex currency and acquisition is negative. There are so many distortions in there that I would rather say why don't you look at September year-to-date. There are only, actually, Asia, then would still show a negative OCI example currency development of minus 2.9%. In Asia then, you have two things in there which is of course, first, the Philippines, which is what I call a welcome dilution effect of the margin, because the Philippines is of course, a new basis for future growth. So if you then take that one out, then Asia ex currency and next acquisition would be down minus 15 3 and would be the only region that you have negative OCI margin developments. Well, now as we were just talking, we found new margins based on revaluation effect in the fourth quarter. Also Asia is going to turn positive by year end, and all four regions, in my opinion, will show positive OCI margin increases even excluding currency and acquisitions. So that is another way of looking at it and is another way of demonstrating that the fundamentals are in very good shape.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of your share buyback comment, as you continue to deliver on the cash flow figures that actually are pretty robust, would you commit to -- when you got this $12 billion of share buyback that's over three year period, but if the cash flow does com
componenttext: In terms of your share buyback comment, as you continue to deliver on the cash flow figures that actually are pretty robust, would you commit to -- when you got this $12 billion of share buyback that's over three year period, but if the cash flow does come in better than expected, would you be open into accelerating the buyback beyond what you are doing in 2010?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: We have made a decision for 2010 to accelerate by $1 billion and to bring it to a $5 billion total for this year. We will take the decision for next year, then at the beginning of next year. I would say, I'll ask your patience, let's talk about next year,
componenttext: We have made a decision for 2010 to accelerate by $1 billion and to bring it to a $5 billion total for this year. We will take the decision for next year, then at the beginning of next year. I would say, I'll ask your patience, let's talk about next year, when we're on next year.

componenttext: The ongoing tax rate is in the range of 29% as it was before. Actually for this year end, if you take the midpoint actually of our guidance increase, and this is $0.125, $0.02 were actually for the tax rate reasons, and $0.08 were for currency and anything between $0.02 and $0.03 were for improved business outlook.

componenttextpreview: So 29% is the ongoing tax rate?
componenttext: So 29% is the ongoing tax rate?

componenttext: It's not more optimistic, it is back to business. It is good pricing in many places around the world. I have been quoting many of them for the fourth quarter, but they may even benefit from those also going into the new year. And also, a pretty good competitive position in many places around the world. So those two together are the basis for the increase on the business.

componenttext: If I summarize that, that sounds like it's the price increases recently announced. Is that fair enough to boil it down to a single point?

componenttext: No. I was just quoting two reasons. It's the price increases on one hand, but it's also the improved competitive position. You heard me in the prepared remarks that our shared performances in the including Marlboro of the many places in the world. It's the combination of the two.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: If I look at your pricing variance over time, because obviously, you got some very tough comps, but at the beginning of this year -- in the course as towards the end of last year, it was either $500 million, and in the fourth quarter it was almost $500 mi
componenttext: If I look at your pricing variance over time, because obviously, you got some very tough comps, but at the beginning of this year -- in the course as towards the end of last year, it was either $500 million, and in the fourth quarter it was almost $500 million. This year it's been consistently below that, $340 million in the first couple of quarters and now $292 million. If you exclude Japan, which is a bit of a one-off, do you think the pricing variance we've had so far this year is the reasonable number to be thinking about going forward? Or do you think 2009 is a better base?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well if you go back one more year, then 2008 was roughly a pricing variance of $1.2 billion. 2009 was actually $2 billion. 2010, they are kind of somewhere in the middle of the two. I would not call it all Japan a one off. That was probably not going to b
componenttext: Well if you go back one more year, then 2008 was roughly a pricing variance of $1.2 billion. 2009 was actually $2 billion. 2010, they are kind of somewhere in the middle of the two. I would not call it all Japan a one off. That was probably not going to be a price increase in Japan next year. However, it is always a mixture of around the world. And there is a mixture of markets, there is also a mixture of timing, and that's what I was alluding to. Okay, the third quarter was a relatively moderate quarter in that sense, but it doesn't mean anything on the fundamentals as you see that this year, the fourth quarter happens to be a strong quarter.

componenttextpreview: Did I hear you correctly that you've applied for or planned to implement price increases in Poland and Ukraine in the fourth quarter?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Not in the Ukraine. In the Ukraine prices have just gone up. There was a price increase, tax increase July 1, that was about all product for one and a half month in the market. Now since mid-August, I would say the consumer has seen the new price. Yes, we
componenttext: Not in the Ukraine. In the Ukraine prices have just gone up. There was a price increase, tax increase July 1, that was about all product for one and a half month in the market. Now since mid-August, I would say the consumer has seen the new price. Yes, we are in the process of implementing a price increases in Poland. That's right. The government there has decided for a tax increase of about 4% as of January. The price increases, however, will come before, and we have applied with customs authorities in Portugal.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Now, Poland has been tough with a tough third quarter with further price hikes. Do you see these levels as reasonable, or do you expect more shock to the volumes there?
componenttext: Now, Poland has been tough with a tough third quarter with further price hikes. Do you see these levels as reasonable, or do you expect more shock to the volumes there?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, I mean, the volume compare is just a bit distorted in the Polish market. You had that situation there, remember, the year-on-year  packed tobacco taxation change. And then you have a lot flowing back into the cigarette markets, so comps are a bit diff
componenttext: No, I mean, the volume compare is just a bit distorted in the Polish market. You had that situation there, remember, the year-on-year  packed tobacco taxation change. And then you have a lot flowing back into the cigarette markets, so comps are a bit difficult there. No, we are pretty happy about the Polish market. We are growing share. We are performing well. Marlboro is growing in the markets. I don't see an underlying problem there.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And just rounding out the EU, if I look at historical numbers correctly, it looks like you won share in the EU for the first time in about seven quarters or longer. I just want to understand because your volumes are still a bit tough in couple of countrie
componenttext: And just rounding out the EU, if I look at historical numbers correctly, it looks like you won share in the EU for the first time in about seven quarters or longer. I just want to understand because your volumes are still a bit tough in couple of countries, but we did see Marlboro win share in some regions as well. I'm wondering if you think this is now a turn, or if there's something structural in the quarter that allowed you to win share optically but likely could still be challenged there on the trade down basis.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I really think what we see are in initiatives on the new Marlboro architecture on innovation about Marlboro, that this is really bearing fruit around the world, one part limited to Europe. And there are of course -- and in addition to that, there are alwa
componenttext: I really think what we see are in initiatives on the new Marlboro architecture on innovation about Marlboro, that this is really bearing fruit around the world, one part limited to Europe. And there are of course -- and in addition to that, there are always some more difficult countries in Europe. That would be Germany, where Marlboro still is held back but there is more or less -- the reason for that is increased price gaps because of rebates given on big and what they call maxi packs, that's packs of 30 cigarettes, or 28, 29. So that's more of a price gap issue, but if you take it all together, really, many other markets in Europe where we are doing well. That's for Marlboro. For the overall share. We should never forget that the orders have also the number two brand in the EU region so we are very, very strongly positioned with the number one and the number two at the top end and at the low-end of the markets.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: On Pakistan, your press release indicated growth. I just wanted to understand if there was organic growth there, given the floods and the impact on distribution in the quarter.
componenttext: On Pakistan, your press release indicated growth. I just wanted to understand if there was organic growth there, given the floods and the impact on distribution in the quarter.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of consumer uptake, that's very hard to say what the situation there in fact is. And then, these floods as we all know covered in the area as big as Italy. When it comes to shipments in our case, those shipments are actually up, but it is a load
componenttext: In terms of consumer uptake, that's very hard to say what the situation there in fact is. And then, these floods as we all know covered in the area as big as Italy. When it comes to shipments in our case, those shipments are actually up, but it is a load and deload thing. We have some trade notes in this quarter, Q3 2010, heard of rumors of price increases. There is in Q3 2009, there was actually a deload in the market, because there occurred a price increase in June, 2009. So it's easy comps in a sense, therefore our shipments are up in Pakistan. The one thing that concerns me a bit more in Pakistan is that we see the non-tax paid segment, let me call it, which now is approaching 20% of consumption in the market.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Finally, Hermann, on your guidance, you gave us a breakdown of the $0.125. You also boosted the buy back plans in the quarter. Do you not see that as having an impact on your earnings in the fourth quarter,, or is that built in the $0.02 to $0.03 business
componenttext: Finally, Hermann, on your guidance, you gave us a breakdown of the $0.125. You also boosted the buy back plans in the quarter. Do you not see that as having an impact on your earnings in the fourth quarter,, or is that built in the $0.02 to $0.03 business outlook?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, I guess, the additional share buybacks in the fourth quarter only have minimal effect on the EPS growth of this year. So the divisor, if you like, when you go for EPS per share is essentially a daily weighted average, i.e., the share repurchases at th
componenttext: No, I guess, the additional share buybacks in the fourth quarter only have minimal effect on the EPS growth of this year. So the divisor, if you like, when you go for EPS per share is essentially a daily weighted average, i.e., the share repurchases at the end of the year have very little impact on your EPS rates of the year, however then, you kind of actually imagine that the comps are put back to zero on January 1 of the subsequent year, so you do get the full benefit than actually the year thereafter we allocate in 2011. But no meaningful impact actually on EPS growth rate of this year. The $0.025, $0.02 to $0.03 that I was quoting is real underlying business.,

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ann Gurkin from Davenport.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ann Gurkin from Davenport.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can I just get an update on the fine-cut tobacco market and your strategy for that market?
componenttext: Can I just get an update on the fine-cut tobacco market and your strategy for that market?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Fine-cut tobacco market is essentially in the international arena, the most important part of it is in Europe. We are doing well in there. You know that we had a couple of take-on acquisitions of some brands there. We are doing alright. We keep on going o
componenttext: Fine-cut tobacco market is essentially in the international arena, the most important part of it is in Europe. We are doing well in there. You know that we had a couple of take-on acquisitions of some brands there. We are doing alright. We keep on going on the other hand, the focus should be cigarettes, because the margins are higher in cigarettes. And very often, this is a question of taxation of [indiscernible] than to remember that's why you had a steep increase a year ago in Spain until the fixation was corrected. Since then, things are back to normal. Yes, we are an active player in the market and things are going okay, I would say.

componenttext: I think the best estimates for now is that the EU commission will come out with defined standards towards the end of 2011, towards the end of next year. The implementation probably in the year 2012. We are of course in discussion with several suppliers of what the cost of such different paper would be on an industrial scale. As you know, there are several techniques that can be used to achieve the desired result and these discussions are going on with various suppliers. You will understand that I would rather refrain from giving a cost estimate. Let's wait for the outcome of those discussions and negotiations.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, rate trends are actually not growing much. They are stable at around 12% to 13% in the market. Our market share situation, and in particular the market share situation of Marlboro is driven by increased price gaps in that market. Remember, a year ago
componenttext: No, rate trends are actually not growing much. They are stable at around 12% to 13% in the market. Our market share situation, and in particular the market share situation of Marlboro is driven by increased price gaps in that market. Remember, a year ago or so we had those price skirmishes around soft packs that has disappeared. Now we have a price skirmishes for rebates for big and bigger packs, 25s up to 30s packs. There are rebates now in the market for packs if you would reconvert it to 19s packs that go up to $0.23 per pack. So that's the competitive situation there. We, of course, had to follow, and we have just launched by the way a Marlboro Maxi Pack EUR 6.90 for 29s there. So that's a bit the situation in Germany. It's not about the brands. It is about industry, competitors bringing tax of the rebates as the justification of those acts.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010

componenttext: In Spain, it seems like you're encountering given the problems of the Spanish market and the Spanish economy and general, but Marlboro should be grown. I mean, is that just the reversal of what's going on in Germany, just the price would actually close or is there something else going on within the Spanish market?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, in all fairness, I have to say that the Marlboro share during the summer period, when the tourists are coming into Spain is always higher, so there is a benefit on Marlboro on that clearly. However, we have somebody searching some preliminary evidence
componenttext: No, in all fairness, I have to say that the Marlboro share during the summer period, when the tourists are coming into Spain is always higher, so there is a benefit on Marlboro on that clearly. However, we have somebody searching some preliminary evidence that it was not only the foreign tourists that were smoking more Marlboros than before, it was also localized Spanish tourists during the holiday period. I think that August will, for the future, once the economy in Spain will recover. And this is just another proof of really of the vibrancy of the Marlboro brand in that market and good prospects going forward.

componenttextpreview: It's correct that the lower house yesterday voted for an increase of specific tax, not that it was unchanged. From a previously foreseen amount of MXN 1.20 per pack to MXN 7. The legislative process is still ongoing. The Senate wrote, and that process is
componenttext: It's correct that the lower house yesterday voted for an increase of specific tax, not that it was unchanged. From a previously foreseen amount of MXN 1.20 per pack to MXN 7. The legislative process is still ongoing. The Senate wrote, and that process is outstanding. The key question, I believe, is can and will those MXN 7 per pack be split over a period over several years, which I think would make imminent sense.

componenttextpreview: On Turkey, looks like sequentially, turkey's getting a little bit easier in terms of volumes. Is that just the consumer getting used to the new price points from January, or is there anything else going on there that means that those volume seems to be st
componenttext: On Turkey, looks like sequentially, turkey's getting a little bit easier in terms of volumes. Is that just the consumer getting used to the new price points from January, or is there anything else going on there that means that those volume seems to be stabilizing a little bit? And then just In terms of Russia, played by the tends again, just through the quarter, whether you can talk about whether those trends are getting better through the period, whether there's any negative impacts? Obviously, as far as the heat wave, it's a bit disrupted during the period in Russia. Whether there's also -- and whether there's an update on what's going on with tax increases moving forward. I know this meant to be good visibility on that, but it seems to me newest rate coming out that, that may change slightly. So I wonder what your position is on that in Russia moving forward.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Turkey, take it as a country first, from last year's already excellent. GDP is up 10%, purchasing power is up. Unemployment is down. Inflation is at fairly low levels for Turkish standards, 6.5%. So consumer confidence is up, all there together, I think,
componenttext: Turkey, take it as a country first, from last year's already excellent. GDP is up 10%, purchasing power is up. Unemployment is down. Inflation is at fairly low levels for Turkish standards, 6.5%. So consumer confidence is up, all there together, I think, we see that consumers have adjusted a little bit to the prices. That being said, prices are extremely high we see negative mix in that market, because price gaps are also high. I believe that about the story about Turkey. Moving over to Russia, there are two things here. I mean, really the down trading that which we see facing out, and we get all clear and hard numbers here. If I look at our distributor sales then premium sales in Q3. Premium Is down minus 3.5%. In Q1, this was down 12.2%, you can see a huge improvement. Mid down 6.3% in Q3 versus 11% in Q1 and low increasing 8% versus 11% in Q1. Our brands, same thing. Q3, Parliament, up 2.3%; Chesterfield, 6.7% up; Bond Street,  20% up; and Optima 1% up. So you clearly can't see down-trading, phasing out in that market. When it comes to excise tax, while the present proposal has gone through the first screening at the that proposal means roughly are all over RUB 3 per pack. So that's an increase about inflation but I wouldn't call it disruptive. The legislates process, however, is not yet over. But for now things look reasonable.

componenttextpreview: I think I can actually answer both questions at the same time, because, they, of course, go together. I mean, at the end of the day, the way we look at this is we look at our projections of our operating cash flow. From there, we would look at capital exp
componenttext: I think I can actually answer both questions at the same time, because, they, of course, go together. I mean, at the end of the day, the way we look at this is we look at our projections of our operating cash flow. From there, we would look at capital expenditure requirements we would look at our capital expenditure requirements we have,  mid and long term or average would be that it should about equal at max depreciation and amortization, then that you look at your multi-year average of what you might need for take-on acquisitions, take a multiyear average of $1 billion or so for the take-ons. Then you would kind of put the framework around that our credit rating are A credit rating gives us. We like our credit-rating. We want to keep that credit rating, because it gives us all the flexibility in the world. So within those ratings, then you get to your dividends. Our dividend payout ratio is 65%. You know that. You also have seen our last dividend increase in there. And from there, you get to the share repurchases, which kind of is the remainder of that whole calculation.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: One is Australia, you had a big tax rise. Are you able to say briefly, what happens with volumes and what happens to profits in that market? And secondly, on pricing, if you look at your merging markets, would you say that typically your pricing is above
componenttext: One is Australia, you had a big tax rise. Are you able to say briefly, what happens with volumes and what happens to profits in that market? And secondly, on pricing, if you look at your merging markets, would you say that typically your pricing is above inflation in those markets, and if so, roughly how much? In very broad terms, how should I think about it?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: So let's first go to Australia. The total market decline is moderating and Australia. It is down about 14% since the April tax increase, but more recently, we've seen about 6% decline, so it is moderating. When it comes to profitability, we have solid sin
componenttext: So let's first go to Australia. The total market decline is moderating and Australia. It is down about 14% since the April tax increase, but more recently, we've seen about 6% decline, so it is moderating. When it comes to profitability, we have solid single digit OCI growth in debt markets so is there is real increase in profitability still and Australia. So from that sense, it's good. By the way, there is really no news in packaging in that market. The government is now studying that situation, and we remain confident that they will recognize and then eventually legal exposure and finally listen to the common sense arguments there that the combination of high prices, product display packaging will do nothing else but facilitate illicit business of criminals, so much on Australia. then on more general pricing question. It always is the situation that we really taken the market-by-market basis. Our price increases in Russia would have been clearly above inflation. In Indonesia, we've just been slightly above inflation. So it is, like always, there is really no general answer. I can't give a generalized answer. It is on the market-by-market basis depending on what is the competitive situation, what is the purchasing power, what are the unemployment into the market, what else is happening, what is the consumer confidence level in the markets. So these are all elements that go into it. So I only can give you examples for the past four key markets like Indonesia and Russia.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, and welcome to the Philip Morris International Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call. Today's call is scheduled to last about one hour, including remarks by Philip Morris International management and the question-and-answer session. (Opera
componenttext:
Good day, and welcome to the Philip Morris International Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call. Today's call is scheduled to last about one hour, including remarks by Philip Morris International management and the question-and-answer session. (Operator Instructions) Media representatives on the call will also be invited to ask questions at the conclusion of questions from the investment community.
I will now turn the call over to Mr. Nick Rolli, Vice President of Investor Relations and Financial Communications. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Welcome. Thank you for joining us. Earlier today, we issued a news release containing detailed information on our 2010 third-quarter results. You may access the release on our website at www.pmi.com.During our call today, we will be talking about result
componenttext:
Welcome. Thank you for joining us. Earlier today, we issued a news release containing detailed information on our 2010 third-quarter results. You may access the release on our website at www.pmi.com.
During our call today, we will be talking about results in the third quarter of 2010 and comparing them with the same period in 2009 unless otherwise stated. References to volumes are for PMI shipments. Industry volume and market shares are the latest data available from a number of internal and external sources. Net revenue data excludes excise taxes. Acquisitions, for the purposes of this presentation, also include our business combination with Fortune Tobacco Corporation in the Philippines. Organic volume refers to volume excluding acquisitions.
You will find data tables showing how we made adjustments to net revenues and operating companies income or OCI, for currency, acquisitions, asset impairment, exit and other costs, free cash flow calculations, and adjustments to earnings per share or EPS, as well as reconciliations to U.S. GAAP measures, at the end of today’s webcast slides, which are posted on our website.
Today’s remarks contain forward-looking statements and projections of future results, and I direct your attention to the Forward-Looking and Cautionary Statements disclosure in today’s presentation and news release for a review of the various factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from projections.
It's now my pleasure to introduce Hermann Waldemer, Chief Financial Officer. Hermann?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Nick, and welcome ladies and gentlemen. As anticipated, our third quarter results were adversely impacted by various timing issues, in particular relating to Japan. More than half our organic volume decline in the quarter was attributable to th
componenttext:
Thank you, Nick, and welcome ladies and gentlemen. As anticipated, our third quarter results were adversely impacted by various timing issues, in particular relating to Japan. More than half our organic volume decline in the quarter was attributable to the payback for the previously disclosed 3.4 billion unit build-up of stocks at our distributor in Japan during the second quarter this year. The lower sales to Japan also drove an unfavorable geographic mix in the quarter.
We do, however, remain very competitive in this important market, where Marlboro is growing share behind innovative line extensions, such as Marlboro Black Menthol and Marlboro Ice Blast, which reached a combined market share of 2% in the quarter.
We continued to face a difficult environment in both Greece and Turkey, resulting from the significant tax increases that occurred earlier this year. Industry volume in these markets was down by 8% and 6%, respectively, in the third quarter, and the widening of price gaps has led to consumer downtrading and an unfavorable product mix.
These three issues masked an otherwise strong underlying business performance. I would like to mention in particular the good results of Marlboro, driven by the new architecture and innovative line extensions. The market share of Marlboro was higher or stable in the third quarter across all four of our regions.
A notable highlight of the quarter was our continued strong cash flow performance, with operating cash flow increasing by more than 30% in the third quarter. This allowed us to accelerate the implementation of our share repurchase program and to increase our dividend by 10.3% in September.
Indeed the strength of our underlying business, along with more favorable exchange rates and a lower tax rate, has led us to raise and narrow our reported diluted EPS guidance for 2010 to a range of $3.90 to $3.95. This represents a reported diluted EPS growth rate of approximately 20% to 22%, compared to the $3.24 achieved last year. Excluding currency, the growth rate in our guidance is now approximately 16% to 18% compared to 14% to 17% projected previously.
Our cigarette volume in the quarter increased by 4.5% to 229.2 billion units, driven by our successful business combination with Fortune Tobacco in the Philippines. Excluding acquisitions, our volume declined by 2.9%, or 6.3 billion units.
In addition to Japan, Ukraine contributed 2.6 billion units to this decline, reflecting both the timing of shipments and market contraction following a series of tax-driven price increases. Our volume was also unfavorably influenced by lower industry volumes in such markets as Greece, Poland, Spain, and Turkey.
On a year-to-date basis, our organic volume was down by 1.6% or 10.5 billion units. The decline was driven in particular by Turkey and Ukraine, whose combined volume was down 10.1 billion units, as well as by Greece and Spain. Our volume in a number of important emerging markets, including Algeria, Argentina, Egypt, Indonesia, Korea, Mexico, and Russia has, however, increased this year.
Our net revenues, excluding currency and acquisitions, were down slightly in the quarter, impacted in particular by the timing of shipments to Japan, the need to partially absorb taxes and lower volumes in Greece, lower volumes and an unfavorable mix in Turkey, and the lapping of last year’s price increase in Germany. On a year-to-date basis, our net revenues, excluding currency and acquisitions, are up 3.6%.
Our OCI in the third quarter was unfavorably impacted by two timing effects and difficult comparisons, namely the aforementioned timing of Japanese shipments and pricing, as well as the tax-driven industry volume declines and unfavorable mix in Greece and Turkey, and lower industry volumes in Spain and Ukraine.
During the third quarter last year, we achieved a record pricing variance of $590 million. Our pricing variance in the third quarter this year was $292 million, as we notably lapped price increases in Germany and Turkey, and were obliged to partially absorb higher taxes in Greece. Consequently, we were not able to fully offset the lower volume and unfavorable geographic mix in this quarter, and adjusted OCI declined by 1.7%, excluding currency and acquisitions, while adjusted diluted EPS grew at the slower rate of 5.4%, excluding currency.
On a year-to-date basis, adjusted OCI increased by 4.5%, excluding currency and acquisitions. These results were impacted by lower volumes, the skew of our pricing variance this year towards the fourth quarter, and higher costs, which we were able to partially offset through our productivity program.
As previously disclosed, tobacco leaf price increases are expected to have an impact of around $215 million for the full year 2010. In addition, we have increased our investments in marketing, sales, R&D and infrastructure. Going forward, we expect tobacco leaf price increases to be broadly in line with inflation and we will continue our rigorous focus on cost controls and productivity gains. Our adjusted diluted EPS growth so far this year was 12.5%, excluding currency.
The underlying strength of our business and favorable pricing prospects are the basis for our confidence in our full year guidance.
We expect to reap the benefit in the fourth quarter of recently implemented price increases in Argentina, Indonesia, Italy, Japan, Russia and the U.K. In addition, we have announced a price increase of EUR0.30 across our portfolio in France, higher prices as of next month in Poland, and have filed for a price increase with the customs authorities in Portugal.
Furthermore, we will benefit substantially in the fourth quarter from the revaluation of the inventories at our distributor in Japan. This represents the increased margin on our future sales to the trade, but from an accounting perspective was taken in October in one go due to our import structure in this market. We therefore expect our pricing variance in the fourth quarter this year to be significantly higher than in the third quarter.
Our underlying business performed strongly in the third quarter, with a share gain for the company and for Marlboro in the EU region, and good share momentum across all regions. PMI achieved year-on-year or sequential share growth notably in Algeria, Argentina, Egypt, Greece, Indonesia, Korea, Mexico, the Netherlands, Poland, Russia, Serbia, Spain, and Turkey.
A key driver of our improved business momentum has been the successful rollout of the new Marlboro architecture. In the third quarter, the share of Marlboro increased or was stable in all four of our regions.
The market share of Marlboro in the EU region grew by 0.2 points in the third quarter to 18.4%, with solid performances notably in Belgium, Italy, the Netherlands, Poland and Spain. In the highly price-sensitive German market, Marlboro’s recovery is being hampered by a widening of price gaps. In Greece, consumers have been downtrading due to steep price increases and enlarged price gaps in a difficult economic environment.
L&M is the second best selling cigarette brand in the EU region after Marlboro. Its strong momentum continued in the third quarter, with market share growth notably in Belgium, the Czech Republic, Germany, Greece, the Netherlands, Poland, Portugal, and Slovakia. For the region as a whole, L&M grew by 0.6 share points to 6.3%.
Outside the EU region, Marlboro is performing very strongly, with market share gains across a wide range of different geographies. Marlboro volume increased by 9.8% in Asia, excluding Japan, was up 0.8% in the Latin America and Canada region, and was down only marginally in the EEMA region.
Let me now turn to our momentum in key markets, starting with the EU region. In the third quarter, total industry volume was down 5.5%, driven primarily by the recession-related double-digit decline of the Spanish market, the combination of price elasticity this year and trade purchase patterns last year in the Polish market, and the impact of higher prices and the economic crisis in Greece. Our total market share in the EU region increased by 0.2 points in the third quarter to 39.1%, behind an overall solid performance across our main markets.
In Greece, our market share is increasing sequentially, as the growth of L&M has more than offset the decline in Marlboro. To maintain the competitiveness of Marlboro, we were obliged to partially absorb tax increases that occurred earlier this year. We expect that the Greek market will continue to act as a drag on our regional profitability growth into the beginning of next year, while discussions on structural changes to the excise tax system continue.
We increased our shipment volume in the very important Russian market by 1.4% in the third quarter to a record level of 25.4 billion units. This strong performance was driven by above premium Parliament, mid-price Chesterfield and low-price Bond Street and Next. PMI implemented price increases of 2 to 3 Rubles per pack in July. The market is stabilizing overall and consumer downtrading continues to slow.
Industry volume during the third quarter in Ukraine is estimated to have been down about 15%, reflecting the size of trade purchases in June ahead of the latest tax increases, and a market contraction resulting from continuous price increases over the last two years. Our volume declined by 2.6 billion units, or about one quarter. Premium Marlboro and mid-price Chesterfield gained share, but we shed share at the low end of the market. The improved mix and higher prices enabled us to strongly increase our profitability in Ukraine during the third quarter.
While the decline slowed in the third quarter, industry volume in Turkey was still down by about 6% year-on-year, as consumers have switched to contraband cigarettes and loose tobacco, following the very large tax-driven price increases earlier this year. Though our volume and product mix remains unfavorable compared to last year, our market share in Turkey is starting to improve sequentially, which makes us optimistic that the outlook will be better next year after a difficult 2010.
While our shipments to Japan in the third quarter were 3.5 billion units below the prior year, sales by our distributor to the trade rose by 4 billion units, or 27.3%. We estimate that the retail trade built up about 10 days of additional stock and consumers purchased some three weeks of stock ahead of the October 2010 retail price increase. Consequently, retail sales this month have been very limited and we will only be able to see the consumers’ reaction to the higher prices towards the end of the quarter and during the first part of next year.
Let me remind you that the retail selling price for cigarettes grew very significantly this month, with a 37.5% increase for Marlboro. While the price increases are unprecedented in their magnitude and take place in a deflationary environment, cigarettes remain relatively affordable and, therefore, we are optimistic that our profitability will be enhanced going forward.
Industry volume in Indonesia grew by a further 3.9% in the quarter, broadly in line with the annual trend. Our shipments were up 3.1% in the third quarter, despite the temporarily unfavorable impact on A Mild, the leading brand in Indonesia, of passing through the 10,000 Rupiah per pack price point. Our overall market share was down 0.2 points, while our profitability in Indonesia grew at a double-digit rate in the quarter, thanks to higher prices and the growing volumes.
In Korea, PMI volume increased by 9.7% in the third quarter, and our market share grew by 2.4 points to 17%, thanks in particular to Marlboro and Parliament, whose growth in recent quarters in Korea has been nothing less than spectacular. Meanwhile, as elsewhere in the world, PMI continues to advocate for the adoption of a system of regular, moderate excise tax increases.
In the Latin America and Canada region, overall industry volume in key markets was essentially stable in the quarter. The Canadian market grew by 4.2%, a slower pace that reflects the fact that we have lapped the period last year when the provincial authorities in Quebec and Ontario started to increase their enforcement against contraband sales. The markets in Argentina and Mexico were down slightly. Our strong share growth continued in the quarter in the key markets of Argentina and Mexico. In the latter, Marlboro continued to grow share and has now captured nearly half the market, helped by the rollout of the new architecture.
Excluding currency and acquisitions, OCI in the quarter was up 2.2%, driven by higher pricing that was partly offset by lower volumes and an unfavorable mix in Canada, where low-price brands have become more prominent following the decline in the illicit trade. In the fourth quarter, profitability will be enhanced by the recently announced retail price increase of 0.5 Peso in Argentina.
Our working capital reduction program is reinforcing our tremendous cash flow generation. In the third quarter this year, our operating cash flow was 30.9% higher at $2.4 billion. Excluding currency, operating cash flow was up by 43.6%. Free cash flow increased at the slightly faster rates of 33.6%, and 47.4% excluding currency.
On a year-to-date basis, our operating cash flow has reached $7.9 billion, for a cumulative total of $23.7 billion since the beginning of 2008. With one quarter to go, we have already surpassed the $21.7 billion cumulative three-year operating cash flow target that we established at the spin by nearly 10%.
Our financial strength enables us to generously reward our shareholders. Thanks to the continued strong growth of our cash flow, we have increased our allocation for share repurchases for the full year to $5 billion, accelerating the rate of purchases this year under our previously approved program by $1 billion more than originally foreseen. In the third quarter, we spent $1.1 billion to purchase an additional 20.7 million shares and have spent $3.9 billion in all so far this year to buy 78.5 million shares.
In September, we increased our quarterly dividend by 10.3% to $0.64 a share, an annualized rate of $2.56. In fact, since the March 2008 spin, we have raised our dividend by 39% and our dividend yield stands at 4.5%.
So let me now summarize why we believe we continue to be an attractive investment opportunity.
We have strong business momentum going into the fourth quarter, and will benefit from higher margins in Japan, as well as price increases in Argentina, France, Indonesia, Italy, Poland, Portugal, Russia, and the U.K. We also have a more favorable currency tailwind than previously factored into our forecast and a lower tax rate. Consequently, we are raising and narrowing our reported diluted EPS guidance for 2010 to a range of $3.90 to $3.95. Compared to 2009, this represents a strong growth rate of approximately 20% to 22%.
We have market leadership and are growing volume and overall share in emerging markets. Marlboro is performing well behind its new brand architecture and innovative line extensions, with overall share up in the EU region in the third quarter, and either increasing or stable in our three other regions.
Our pricing power remains strong due to our brand leadership and broad portfolio. The outlook for costs going forward is improving. Our growing cash flow has enabled us to accelerate our share repurchase program this year to a total spending target of $5 billion, and we raised our dividend by 10.3% in September, thus providing attractive returns to our shareholders.
Thank you. I will now be pleased to answer any questions you may have.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask you three things, Hermann. First, with respect to pricing in the quarter, you highlighted a number of comparative issues, timing issues, you talked about the fourth quarter. But if you step back, do you feel as if there has been any modera
componenttext: I wanted to ask you three things, Hermann. First, with respect to pricing in the quarter, you highlighted a number of comparative issues, timing issues, you talked about the fourth quarter. But if you step back, do you feel as if there has been any moderation in your broad global capacity to raise pricing either because of consumer resistance or competitive dynamics?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. No, I don't see a moderation there. We continue to do what we did last year and the year before. We look at every market, we take our decisions on a market-by-market basis. I see no fundamentals - underlying fundamentals that would have changed.
componenttext: Okay. No, I don't see a moderation there. We continue to do what we did last year and the year before. We look at every market, we take our decisions on a market-by-market basis. I see no fundamentals - underlying fundamentals that would have changed.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. Secondly, Hermann, I know you are not going to discretely comment about the outlook for next year. But would you agree there are a number of dynamics that should slow the results next year? You are going to have significant pricing in Japan where pr
componenttext:
Okay. Secondly, Hermann, I know you are not going to discretely comment about the outlook for next year. But would you agree there are a number of dynamics that should slow the results next year? You are going to have significant pricing in Japan where presumably profits prior to this increase have been on a downward trend, you have FX in your favor, you are seeing some improvements in the EM - in emerging markets, you are going to get some cost savings in the Philippines, and the buyback will continue.
Do you agree with those sort of - not that there won't be negative dynamics next year, but you certainly will go into next year with those things in your favor.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, absolutely. I don't know about forex, because nobody knows about foreign exchange the way it looks now today. Yes, Japan, of course we have tremendous margin increases in there. We all know that we have to see what the consumer reaction is. Yes, we d
componenttext: Yes, absolutely. I don't know about forex, because nobody knows about foreign exchange the way it looks now today. Yes, Japan, of course we have tremendous margin increases in there. We all know that we have to see what the consumer reaction is. Yes, we do have a very strong position in emerging markets, further reinforced of course by the business combination in the Philippines and beyond that, of course fantastic position there. Yes, there are certainly cost synergies as well that we can find there. Overall, I would also say that we will certainly keep our cost focus and productivity focus also in the next year.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then lastly, Hermann, in Japan, am I right thinking that this one-off windfall from the revaluation of inventory, maybe that's $100 million or $120 million?
componenttext: Okay. And then lastly, Hermann, in Japan, am I right thinking that this one-off windfall from the revaluation of inventory, maybe that's $100 million or $120 million?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Might be even slightly better than that.
componenttext: Might be even slightly better than that.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. Although that's truly one-off, correct? I mean, that's sort of a windfall. That - you will be less of that next year when you look at the fourth quarter?
componenttext: Okay. Although that's truly one-off, correct? I mean, that's sort of a windfall. That - you will be less of that next year when you look at the fourth quarter?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, that's not a windfall. Really what it is there is this reflects the increased margins on our products. In a different situation and different structure in the market, you would realize those additional margins simply as you sell your products out to t
componenttext:
No, that's not a windfall. Really what it is there is this reflects the increased margins on our products. In a different situation and different structure in the market, you would realize those additional margins simply as you sell your products out to the consumer.
We have an import structure in the Japanese market, which only means that on the inventories at the distributor, you take this margin increase in one go already in the month of October, which otherwise would have come in kind of every day. So it's not at all a windfall. It is simply reflecting the increased margins in that market going forward.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010

componenttext: Okay. Thanks a lot.
