headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just on Japan, so all of the inventory that got built up in the second quarter, would you say that that has been now kind of flushed out at the shipment level now so that in the fourth quarter, it really would be a reflection of what the consumer dynamic
componenttext: Just on Japan, so all of the inventory that got built up in the second quarter, would you say that that has been now kind of flushed out at the shipment level now so that in the fourth quarter, it really would be a reflection of what the consumer dynamic would look like?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, we have inventories in the market that's kind of on the basis of the middle-of-the-road assumption we consider to be reasonable. Now, of course we will see what the real consumer reaction is and you always have to adopt then inventories to yo
componenttext: Yes. I mean, we have inventories in the market that's kind of on the basis of the middle-of-the-road assumption we consider to be reasonable. Now, of course we will see what the real consumer reaction is and you always have to adopt then inventories to your prospective sales. But I believe that we are on a very reasonable base just there, which is baked in into our full year guidance.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on - and then just staying on Japan, in terms of - going back to David's question, so you have the margin improvement from the higher pricing that you have taken, but also have the favorable revelation of I think about $32 million that shou
componenttext: Okay. And then on - and then just staying on Japan, in terms of - going back to David's question, so you have the margin improvement from the higher pricing that you have taken, but also have the favorable revelation of I think about $32 million that should benefit you in the fourth quarter?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: No. I mean, the secret in Japan has simply been that if I go quarter by quarter, you have the inventory buildup in second, you have to pay back for that in the third. There is no tax windfall in the market in Japan that is taken by the government. Every p
componenttext:
No. I mean, the secret in Japan has simply been that if I go quarter by quarter, you have the inventory buildup in second, you have to pay back for that in the third. There is no tax windfall in the market in Japan that is taken by the government. Every product sold as of October 1, the new tax has to be paid and gets to the government.
So, now what's coming in now is really the additional margin on the stock at the distributor which we have. That additional margin that is made on the inventories at the retail stays with the retailer. That's the only thing there.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, okay. All right. And then just kind of taking a step back and looking at your operating profit in the third quarter, obviously a lot of negative impact from Japan and so forth, but if you adjust for Japan and the tax absorption in Greece, is there -
componenttext: Okay, okay. All right. And then just kind of taking a step back and looking at your operating profit in the third quarter, obviously a lot of negative impact from Japan and so forth, but if you adjust for Japan and the tax absorption in Greece, is there - are you able to quantify how much adjusted operating income ex currency and ex acquisition would have been in the third quarter?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, there is - okay, there is two ways of looking at that. I mean, the first one, adjusted growth rate, well, let's put it this way. Japan alone is about a 4 percentage point drag on PMI's results in the quarter. And Greece and Turkey together would add
componenttext:
Yes, there is - okay, there is two ways of looking at that. I mean, the first one, adjusted growth rate, well, let's put it this way. Japan alone is about a 4 percentage point drag on PMI's results in the quarter. And Greece and Turkey together would add another 2 percentage points.
But actually - maybe an even better way to answer your question is really to look at OCI margins, because in the third quarter there is the overall PMI ex currency and acquisition is negative. There are so many distortions in there that I would rather say, why don't we look at September year-to-date.
There on the - actually Asia, and then would still show a negative OCI ex currency development of minus 2.9%. In Asia, then you have two things in there, which is of course first, the Philippines which is what I call a welcome dilution effect of the margin, because the Philippines is of course a new basis for future growth. So if you then take that one out, then Asia ex currency and ex acquisition would be down minus 1.3% and would be the only region where you have negative OCI margin developments.
Well, now, as we were just talking, we found new margins and we use the revaluation effect in the fourth quarter. Also, Asia is going to turn positive by year-end and all four regions, in my opinion, will show positive OCI margin increases even excluding currency and acquisitions. So that is another way of looking at it and is another way of demonstrating that the fundamentals are in very good shape.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then finally, in terms of your share buyback comments, so as you continue to deliver on the cash flow figures that actually are pretty robust, would you commit to - you've got this $12 billion of share buyback that's over a three-year period, bu
componenttext: Okay. And then finally, in terms of your share buyback comments, so as you continue to deliver on the cash flow figures that actually are pretty robust, would you commit to - you've got this $12 billion of share buyback that's over a three-year period, but if the cash flow does come in better than expected, would you be open to accelerating the buyback beyond what you are doing in 2010?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we have made a decision for 2010 to accelerate by $1 billion and to bring it to a $5 billion total for this year. We will take the decision for next year then at the beginning of the next year, I would say. So I ask your patience, let's talk about n
componenttext: Well, we have made a decision for 2010 to accelerate by $1 billion and to bring it to a $5 billion total for this year. We will take the decision for next year then at the beginning of the next year, I would say. So I ask your patience, let's talk about next year when we are in next year.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks, Hermann.
componenttext: Okay. Thanks, Hermann.

componenttext: Thank you.

componenttext: Hi, Hermann. Can I ask you a couple of questions? The first simple one is you talked about tax rates going down. Can you sort of give some guidance about what the ongoing tax rate is likely to be?

componenttext: Well, the ongoing tax rate is in the range of 29%, as it was before. Actually, for this year and I mean, if you take the midpoint actually of our guidance increase, then this is $0.125, $0.02 were actually for the tax reason - tax rate reasons, $0.08 were for currency, and anything between $0.02 and $0.03 were for improved business outlook.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm sorry, I missed that. Is - 29% is the ongoing tax rate?
componenttext: I'm sorry, I missed that. Is - 29% is the ongoing tax rate?

componenttext: Yes. How about $0.02 or $0.03 increase you just mentioned just a second ago? Geographically, can you sort of say where you've got more optimistic?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: So, more optimistic, it is a better business, it is good pricing in many places around the world. I have been quoting many of them for the fourth quarter. By the way, we will benefit from those also going into the New Year, and also a pretty good competit
componenttext: So, more optimistic, it is a better business, it is good pricing in many places around the world. I have been quoting many of them for the fourth quarter. By the way, we will benefit from those also going into the New Year, and also a pretty good competitive position in many places around the world. So, those two together are the basis for the increase on the business.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: If I summarize that, that sounds like use the price increases you've recently announced. Is that fair enough to boil it down to -?
componenttext: If I summarize that, that sounds like use the price increases you've recently announced. Is that fair enough to boil it down to -?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: No. It's - as I was just quoting, two reasons, it's the price increases on one hand, but it's also the improved competitive position. You heard me in this - in the prepared remarks that our share performances including Marlboro over many places in the wor
componenttext: No. It's - as I was just quoting, two reasons, it's the price increases on one hand, but it's also the improved competitive position. You heard me in this - in the prepared remarks that our share performances including Marlboro over many places in the world, it's the combination of the two.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much. One final question. If I look at your pricing variance over time, obviously you've got some very tough comps. But at the beginning of this year - well, last year - in the context, toward the end of last year, it was over $500 million
componenttext:
Thank you very much. One final question. If I look at your pricing variance over time, obviously you've got some very tough comps. But at the beginning of this year - well, last year - in the context, toward the end of last year, it was over $500 million and then in the fourth quarter, it was almost $500 million. This year, it's been consistently below that, $340 million in the first couple of quarters and now, $292 million.
Now, if you exclude Japan, which is a bit of a one-off, do you think - I suppose the question is, do you think the pricing variance we have had so far this year is a reasonable number to be thinking about going forward or do you think 2009 is a better base?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, if you go back one more year, then 2008 was roughly a pricing variance of $1.2 billion, 2009 was actually $2 billion, 2010 kind of somewhere in the middle of the two.I would not call at all Japan a one-off, okay? There was probably not going to be
componenttext:
Well, if you go back one more year, then 2008 was roughly a pricing variance of $1.2 billion, 2009 was actually $2 billion, 2010 kind of somewhere in the middle of the two.
I would not call at all Japan a one-off, okay? There was probably not going to be a price increase in Japan next year. However, it is always a mixture of around the world. And that is a mixture of markets, there is also a mixture of timing and that's what I was alluding to. I mean, okay, the third quarter was a relatively moderate quarter in that sense, but it doesn't mean anything on the fundamentals as I see that this year the fourth quarter happens to be a strong quarter.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you very much.
componenttext: Okay. Thank you very much.

componenttext: You are welcome.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: So there was a price increase - tax increase July 1. There was about all product for one-and-a-half months in the market. Now, since mid-August, I would say the consumer has seen the new price. Yes, we are in the process of implementing a price increase i
componenttext: So there was a price increase - tax increase July 1. There was about all product for one-and-a-half months in the market. Now, since mid-August, I would say the consumer has seen the new price. Yes, we are in the process of implementing a price increase in Poland, that's right. There is - the government there has decided for a tax increase of about 4% as of January. The price increases, however, will come before. And we have applied with customs authorities in Portugal.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: In Portugal? Okay. Now, Poland has been tough, we saw a tough third quarter with further price hikes. Do you see these levels as reasonable or do you expect more shock to the volumes there?
componenttext: In Portugal? Okay. Now, Poland has been tough, we saw a tough third quarter with further price hikes. Do you see these levels as reasonable or do you expect more shock to the volumes there?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: No. I mean, the volume comparisons are just a bit distorted in the Polish market. You had the situation there, remember that earlier on tobacco taxation changed that you had a lot flowing back into the cigarette market. So comps are a bit difficult there.
componenttext: No. I mean, the volume comparisons are just a bit distorted in the Polish market. You had the situation there, remember that earlier on tobacco taxation changed that you had a lot flowing back into the cigarette market. So comps are a bit difficult there. No, we are pretty happy about the Polish market. We are growing share, we are performing well, Marlboro is growing in the market. No, I don't see an underlying problem there.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just rounding off the EU, if I look at historical numbers correctly, it looks like you won share in the EU for the first time in about seven quarters or longer. I just want to understand, because still the Marlboro's - or your volumes are still
componenttext: Okay. And just rounding off the EU, if I look at historical numbers correctly, it looks like you won share in the EU for the first time in about seven quarters or longer. I just want to understand, because still the Marlboro's - or your volumes are still a bit tough in a couple of countries, but we did see Marlboro win share in some regions as well. I'm wondering if you think this is now a turn or if there was something structural in the quarter that allowed you to win optically, but likely could still be challenged there on the trade-down basis.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Anything that we see are in initiatives on the new Marlboro architecture, on innovation about Marlboro that this is really bearing fruits around the world (inaudible) to Europe. Then there are - of course then in addition to that, there are always some mo
componenttext:
Anything that we see are in initiatives on the new Marlboro architecture, on innovation about Marlboro that this is really bearing fruits around the world (inaudible) to Europe. Then there are - of course then in addition to that, there are always some more difficult countries in Europe. That would be Germany where Marlboro still is held back. But there is - more or less, the reason for that is increased price gaps because of rebates given on big and what they call maxi-packs, that's packs of 30 cigarette or 28, 29, 30 cigarette. So that's more of a price gap issue.
But if you take it all together, really many other markets in Europe where we are doing well, that's for Marlboro for the overall share, we should never forget that we always have (inaudible) on them, although the number two brand in the EU region. So we are very, very strong in position, just the number one and the number two at the top end and at the low end of the markets.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks for that. And a couple of final little questions on Pakistan, your press release indicated growth. I just wanted to understand if there was organic growth there, given the floods and the impact on distribution in the quarter.
componenttext: Okay. Thanks for that. And a couple of final little questions on Pakistan, your press release indicated growth. I just wanted to understand if there was organic growth there, given the floods and the impact on distribution in the quarter.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, in terms of consumer off-take, that's very hard to say what the situation there in Pakistan is. I mean, these floods, as we all know, covered an area as big as Italy. When it comes to shipments in our case, those shipments are actually up, but it is
componenttext:
Well, in terms of consumer off-take, that's very hard to say what the situation there in Pakistan is. I mean, these floods, as we all know, covered an area as big as Italy. When it comes to shipments in our case, those shipments are actually up, but it is a load and de-load thing. We had some trade load in this quarter, Q3 2010, ahead of rumors about price increases, whereas in Q3 2009 there was actually a de-load in the market, because there had occurred a price increase in June 2009.
So it's easy comps in a sense, therefore our shipments are up in Pakistan. The one thing that concerns me a bit more in Pakistan is that we see the non-tax paid segment let me call it, which now is approaching 20% of consumption in the market.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And finally, Hermann, on your guidance, you gave us a breakdown of the $0.125, thank you very much. You have also boosted the buyback plan in the fourth quarter. Do you not see that as having an impact on your earnings in the fourth quarter or was t
componenttext: Okay. And finally, Hermann, on your guidance, you gave us a breakdown of the $0.125, thank you very much. You have also boosted the buyback plan in the fourth quarter. Do you not see that as having an impact on your earnings in the fourth quarter or was that built into the $0.02 to $0.03 business outlook?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: No - no, it's - I mean, the additional share buybacks in the fourth quarter only have minimal effect on the EPS growth of this year. So the divisor, if you like, when you go for EPS per share is essentially a daily weighted average, either share purchases
componenttext: No - no, it's - I mean, the additional share buybacks in the fourth quarter only have minimal effect on the EPS growth of this year. So the divisor, if you like, when you go for EPS per share is essentially a daily weighted average, either share purchases at the end of the year have very little impact on your EPS rates of the year, however then you kind of have to imagine that the comps are put back to zero on January 1 of the subsequent year. So, you do get the benefit then actually the year thereafter, in our case in 2011. But no meaningful impact actually on the EPS growth rate of this year, the $0.125, $0.02 to $0.03 that I was quoting is real underlying business.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. Thanks for that, Hermann.
componenttext: Okay, great. Thanks for that, Hermann.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. Fine-cut tobacco market is essentially in the international arena, the most important part is in Europe. We are doing well in there, you know that we had a couple of tack-on acquisitions of some brands there. We are doing all right, we keep on growi
componenttext:
Okay. Fine-cut tobacco market is essentially in the international arena, the most important part is in Europe. We are doing well in there, you know that we had a couple of tack-on acquisitions of some brands there. We are doing all right, we keep on growing.
On the hand, the focus certainly always should be cigarettes, because the margins are higher in cigarettes and very often this is a question of taxation of roll-your-own, make-your-own. And so remember that's why you had a steep increase a year ago in Spain until the taxation there was correct and since then things are back to normal. Yes, we are an active player in the market and things are going okay, I would say.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then secondly, Hermann, I don't know if you will comment with respect to the potential adoption of the use of LIP paper. Have you all made any decisions as to when you would adopt the use of LIP, when you think that requirement will be pu
componenttext: Okay, great. And then secondly, Hermann, I don't know if you will comment with respect to the potential adoption of the use of LIP paper. Have you all made any decisions as to when you would adopt the use of LIP, when you think that requirement will be put through in the EU market and who you might use as your supplier?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, so I think the best estimate for now is that the EU region I think - the EU Commission - sorry, the EU Commission will come out defined standards towards the end of 2011, towards the end of next year, implementation probably in the year 2012.We ar
componenttext:
Well, so I think the best estimate for now is that the EU region I think - the EU Commission - sorry, the EU Commission will come out defined standards towards the end of 2011, towards the end of next year, implementation probably in the year 2012.
We are of course in discussion with several suppliers of what the cost of such different paper would be on an industrial scale. As you know, there are several techniques that can be used to achieve the desired result. As these discussions are going on with various suppliers, you will understand that I will rather refrain from giving a cost estimate. Let's wait for the outcome of those discussions and negotiations.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Is it fair to say you will probably wait to adopt the use of LIP till middle of next year, 2011, or how can you comment on that?
componenttext: Is it fair to say you will probably wait to adopt the use of LIP till middle of next year, 2011, or how can you comment on that?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we will adopt it when the legal requirement is there. I see no reason to do it earlier.
componenttext: Yes, we will adopt it when the legal requirement is there. I see no reason to do it earlier.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, sure. In - secondly, in Germany, the market share loss, is that going toward the branded players or does that represent the growth of the retail brands?
componenttext: Okay, sure. In - secondly, in Germany, the market share loss, is that going toward the branded players or does that represent the growth of the retail brands?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, trade brands are actually not growing much. They are stable at around 12% to 13% in the market. Our market share situation, in particular the market share situation of Marlboro is driven by increased price gaps in that market. Remember, a year ago or
componenttext:
No, trade brands are actually not growing much. They are stable at around 12% to 13% in the market. Our market share situation, in particular the market share situation of Marlboro is driven by increased price gaps in that market. Remember, a year ago or so we had those price curve issues [ph] around soft packs that have disappeared. Now, we have price curve issues in rebates for big and bigger packs, i.e. 25s, up to 30s packs. There are rebates now in the market for packs if you would reconvert that to 19s packs, that go up to $0.23 per pack.
So that's the situation - the competitive situation there. We of course have to follow and we have just launched, by the way, a Marlboro maxi pack EUR6.90 for 29s there. So that's the situation in Germany. It's not about the trade trends. It is about industry competitors bringing packs with rebates as the justification of their size.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And also explain - I mean, it seems like the counter-intuitive given the problems with the Spanish market and Spanish economy in general that Marlboro should be grown. I mean, is that just the reversal of what's going on in Germany, just the price gaps ha
componenttext: And also explain - I mean, it seems like the counter-intuitive given the problems with the Spanish market and Spanish economy in general that Marlboro should be grown. I mean, is that just the reversal of what's going on in Germany, just the price gaps have closed or is there something else going on within the Spanish market?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, Spanish, I have to say that the Marlboro share during the summer period when the tourists are coming into Spain is always higher. So there is a benefit on Marlboro on that clearly.However, we have some research and some preliminary evidence that it
componenttext:
No, Spanish, I have to say that the Marlboro share during the summer period when the tourists are coming into Spain is always higher. So there is a benefit on Marlboro on that clearly.
However, we have some research and some preliminary evidence that it was not only the foreign tourists that were smoking more Marlboros than before, it was also locally Spanish tourists during the holiday period. I think that all goes well for the future once the economy in Spain will recover and it is just another proof of really of the vibrancy of the Marlboro brand in that market and good prospects going forward.

componenttext: Okay. Yes, so it's correct. The Lower House yesterday voted for an increase of specific tax, not on the lower end, that was unchanged, from a previously foreseen amount of 1.20 peso per pack to 7 pesos. The legislative process is still ongoing. The Senate vote in that process is outstanding. The key question I believe is, can and will those 7 pesos per pack be split over a period, i.e. over several years, which I think would make imminent sense.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hi Hermann, two areas if I can. Firstly on Turkey, it looks like sequentially Turkey is getting a little bit easier in terms of volume. Is that just the consumer getting used to the new price points from January or is anything else going on there that mea
componenttext:
Hi Hermann, two areas if I can. Firstly on Turkey, it looks like sequentially Turkey is getting a little bit easier in terms of volume. Is that just the consumer getting used to the new price points from January or is anything else going on there that means that those volumes seem to stabilizing a little bit?
And then just in terms of Russia, clearly better trends again. I just wondered whether the - just through the course, whether you can talk about whether those trends were getting better through the period, whether there was any negative impact? Obviously, there was fires and heat waves, it was a bit disrupted during the period in Russia.
And then just also whether there is an update on what's going on with tax increases moving forward. I know there's not supposed to be good visibility on that, but it seems to be news flow coming out that that may change slightly. I just wonder what your position is on that tax risk in Russia moving forward. Thank you.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. First Turkey then, well, it is simply - I mean, you see Turkey, take it as a country first. The macros are really excellent, GDP is up 10%, purchasing power is up, unemployment is down, inflation is at fairly low levels for Turkey standards, 6.5%. S
componenttext:
Okay. First Turkey then, well, it is simply - I mean, you see Turkey, take it as a country first. The macros are really excellent, GDP is up 10%, purchasing power is up, unemployment is down, inflation is at fairly low levels for Turkey standards, 6.5%. So consumer confidence is up. All that together, I think we see that consumers have adjusted a little bit to the prices. That being said, prices are extremely high and we see negative mix in that market because price gaps are also high. I believe that's about the story about Turkey.
And moving over to Russia, there are two things here. I mean, really the downtrading which we see phasing out, I mean there are clearly clear and hard numbers here. If I look at our distributor sales, then premium sales in Q3 - premium is down minus 3.5%. In Q1, this was down 12.2%, you can see a huge improvement. Mid, down 6.3% in Q3 versus 11% in Q1; and low, increasing 8% versus 11% in Q1. Our brands, same thing. Q3, Parliament, up 2.7%; Chesterfield, 6.7% up; Bond Street, 20% up; and Optima, 1% up. So you clearly can see downtrading is phasing out in that market.
When it comes to excise tax, well, the present proposal has gone through the first reading at the Duma. That proposal means roughly a rollover need of 3 rubles per pack. So that's an increase above inflation, but I wouldn't call it disruptive. The legislative process, however, is not yet over. But for now, things look reasonable.

And secondly, if you could just discuss your plans around leverage? Your leverage ticked up slightly in the quarter and I just wanted to see if you could talk about where you ultimately want to see your leverage. Thank you.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. I think I can actually answer both questions at the same time, because they of course go together. I mean, at the end of the day, the way we look at that is, we look at our projections of our operating cash flow. From there, we would look at our cap
componenttext:
Okay. I think I can actually answer both questions at the same time, because they of course go together. I mean, at the end of the day, the way we look at that is, we look at our projections of our operating cash flow. From there, we would look at our capital expenditure requirements we have; mid and long-term or our multiyear average would there be that it should - about equal at max, depreciation and amortization.
Then, you would look at your multiyear average of what you might need for tack-on acquisitions. Take a multiyear average of $1 billion or so for the tack-ons. Then, you would kind of put the framework around that our credit rating, our A credit rating gives us. We like our credit rating, we want to keep that credit rating because it gives us all the flexibility in the world.
So within those ratings, then you get to your dividends. Our dividend payout ratio is 65%. You know that, you also have seen our last dividend increase in there. And from there, you get to the share repurchases, which kind of use the remainder of that whole calculation.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: First of all, thank you very much for taking the follow-up question. If I can, two very brief ones. One is, Australia, you had a big tax rise. Are you able to say very briefly what happened to volumes and what happened to profit in that market? And second
componenttext: First of all, thank you very much for taking the follow-up question. If I can, two very brief ones. One is, Australia, you had a big tax rise. Are you able to say very briefly what happened to volumes and what happened to profit in that market? And secondly, on pricing, if you look at your emerging markets, would you say that typically your pricing is above inflation in those markets, and if so, roughly how much? I mean, in very broad terms, how should I think about it? Thank you.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. So let's go first to Australia then. Well, the total market decline is moderating in Australia. It is down about 14% since the April tax increase. But more recently, we see now about 6% decline, so it is moderating. When it comes to profitability, w
componenttext:
Okay. So let's go first to Australia then. Well, the total market decline is moderating in Australia. It is down about 14% since the April tax increase. But more recently, we see now about 6% decline, so it is moderating. When it comes to profitability, we have a solid single-digit OCI growth in that market. So there is real increase in profitability still in Australia. So from that sense, it's good.
By the way, there is no really new news on plain packaging in that market. The government is now studying the situation and we remain confident that they will recognize there eventually the exposure and finally listen to the common sense arguments there that the combination of high prices, product display ban, and plain packaging would do nothing else but facilitate illicit business of criminals. So much on Australia.
Then on your more general pricing question, well, it always is a situation that we really take on a market-by-market basis. Our price increases in Russia would have been clearly above inflation. In Indonesia, it would have been above inflation.
So it is - like always, it is really there is no general answer, I'm sorry. I can't give a generalized answer. It is on a market-by-market basis, depending what is the competitive situation, what is the purchasing power, what are the unemployment trends in the market, what else is happening, what is the consumer confidence level in the markets. So these are all elements that go into it. So, I only can give you examples from the past four key markets, like Indonesia and Russia are.

componenttext: Good day, and welcome to the Philip Morris International Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I will now turn the call over to Mr. Nick Rolli, Vice President of Investor Relations and Financial Communications. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Welcome. Thank you for joining us. Earlier today, we issued a news release containing detailed information on our 2010 third quarter results. You may access the release on our website at www.pmi.com.During our call today, we'll be talking about results
componenttext:
Welcome. Thank you for joining us. Earlier today, we issued a news release containing detailed information on our 2010 third quarter results. You may access the release on our website at www.pmi.com.
During our call today, we'll be talking about results in the third quarter of 2010 and comparing them with the same period in 2009, unless otherwise stated. References to volumes are for PMI shipments. Industry volume and market shares are the latest data available from a number of internal and external sources. Net revenue data excludes excise taxes. Acquisitions, for the purposes of this presentation, also include our business combination with Fortune Tobacco Corporation in the Philippines. Organic volume refers to volume excluding acquisitions.
You'll find data tables showing how we made adjustments to net revenues and operating companies income, or OCI, for currency, acquisitions, asset impairment, exit and other costs, free cash flow calculations and adjustments to earnings per share or EPS, as well as reconciliations to U.S. GAAP measures at the end of today's webcast slides, which are posted on our website.
Today's remarks contain forward-looking statements and projections of future results, and I direct your attention to the forward-looking and cautionary statements disclosure in today's presentation and news release for a review of the various factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from projections. It is now my pleasure to introduce Hermann Waldemer, Chief Financial Officer. Hermann?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Nick, and welcome, ladies and gentlemen. As anticipated, our third quarter results were adversely impacted by various timing issues, in particular, relating to Japan. More than half our organic volume decline in the quarter was attributable to
componenttext:
Thank you, Nick, and welcome, ladies and gentlemen. As anticipated, our third quarter results were adversely impacted by various timing issues, in particular, relating to Japan. More than half our organic volume decline in the quarter was attributable to the payback for the previously disclosed 3.4 billion unit build up of stocks at our distributor in Japan during the second quarter this year. The lower sales to Japan also drove an unfavorable geographic mix in the quarter. We do, however, remain very competitive in this important market. The Marlboro is growing share behind innovative line extensions such as Marlboro Black Menthol and Marlboro Ice Blast, which reached the combined market share of 2% in the quarter. 
We continue to face a difficult environment in both Greece and Turkey, resulting from the significant tax increases that occurred earlier this year. Industry volume in these markets was down by 8% and 6% respectively in the third quarter. And dividing of price caps has led to consumer down trading and an unfavorable product mix. 
These three issues masked and underwrites strong underlying business performance. I would like to mention in particular the good results of Marlboro, driven by the new architecture and innovative line extensions. The market share of Marlboro was higher or stable in the third quarter across all four of our regions. 
A notable highlight of the quarter was our continued strong cash flow performance, with operating cash flow increasing by more than 30% in the quarter. This allowed us to accelerate the implementation of our share repurchase program and to increase our dividend by 10.3% in September.
Indeed, the strength of our underlying business along with more favorable exchange rates and the lower tax rate has led us to raise and narrow our reported diluted EPS guidance for 2010 to a range of $3.90 to $3.95. This represents our reported diluted EPS growth rate of approximately 20% to 22% compared to the $3.24 achieved last year. Excluding currency, the growth rate in our guidance is now approximately 16% to 18% compared to 14% to 17%, projected previously.
Our cigarette volume in the quarter increased by 4.5% to 229.2 billion units, driven by our successful business combination with Fortune Tobacco in the Philippines. Excluding acquisitions, our volume declined by 2.9% or 6.3 billion units. In addition to Japan, Ukraine contributed 2.6 billion units to this decline, reflecting both the timing of shipments and market contraction, following a series of tax-driven price increases. Our volume was also unfavorably influenced by lower industry volumes in such markets as Greece, Poland, Spain and Turkey. 
On a year-to-date basis, our organic volume was down by 1.6% or 10.5 billion units. The decline was driven in particular by Turkey and Ukraine, whose combined volume was down 10.1 billion units, as well as by Greece and Spain. Our volume in a number of important emerging markets, including Algeria, Argentina, Egypt, Indonesia, Korea, Mexico and Russia has, however, increased this year. 
Our net revenues, excluding currency and acquisitions were down slightly in the quarter, impacted in particular by the timing of shipments to Japan, the need to partially absorb taxes and lower volumes in Greece, lower volumes and an unfavorable mix in Turkey and the netting of last year's price increase in Germany. On a year-to-date basis, our net revenues, excluding currency and acquisitions, are up 3.6%. 
Our OCI in the third quarter was unfavorably impacted by two timing effects and difficult comparisons, namely, the aforementioned timing of Japanese shipments and pricing, as well as the tax-driven industry volume declines and unfavorable mix in Greece and Turkey and lower industry volumes in Spain and Ukraine. 
During the third quarter last year, we achieved a record pricing variance of $590 million. Our pricing variance in the third quarter this year was $292 million, as we notably lapped price increases in Germany and Turkey and were obliged to partially absorb higher taxes in Greece. Consequently, we were not able to fully offset the lower volume and unfavorable geographic mix in this quarter and adjusted OCI declined by 1.7%, excluding currency and acquisition, while adjusted diluted EPS grew at a slower rate of 5.4% excluding currency. 
On a year-to-date basis, adjusted OCI increased by 4.5%, excluding currency and acquisitions. These results were impacted by lower volumes, the skew of our pricing variance this year towards the fourth quarter and higher costs, which we were able to partially offset through our productivity program. 
As previously disclosed, tobacco leaf prices increases are expected to have an impact of around $215 million for the full year 2010. In addition, we have increased our investments in marketing, sales, R&D and infrastructure. Going forward, we expect tobacco leaf prices increases to be broadly in line with inflation, and we will continue our rigorous focus on cost controls and productivity gains.  
Our adjusted diluted EPS for this year was 12.5%, excluding currency. The underlying strength of our business and favorable pricing prospects are the basis for our confidence in our full year guidance. 
We expect to reap the benefits in the fourth quarter of recently implemented price increases in Argentina, Indonesia, Italy, Japan, Russia and the U.K. In addition, we have announced a price increase of EUR 0.30 across our portfolio in France, higher prices as of next month in Poland and have filed for a price increase with the customs authorities in Portugal. 
Furthermore, we build benefits substantially in the fourth quarter from the revaluation of the inventories at our distributor in Japan. This represents the increased margin on our future sales to the trade, but from an accounting perspective, was taken in October in one go due to our import structure in this market. We therefore expect our pricing variance in the fourth quarter this year to be significantly higher than in the third quarter. 
Our underlying business performed strongly in the third quarter with a share gain for the company and for Marlboro in the EU region and good share momentum across all regions. PMI achieved year-on-year or sequential share growth notably in Nigeria, Argentina, Egypt, Greece, Indonesia, Korea, Mexico, The Netherlands, Poland, Russia, Serbia, Spain and Turkey.
A key driver of our improved business momentum has been the successful rollout of the new Marlboro architecture. In the third quarter, the share of Marlboro increased, or was stable, in all four of our regions. The market share of Marlboro in the EU region grew by 0.2 points in the third quarter to 18.4%. The solid performance is notably in Belgium, Italy, The Netherlands, Poland and Spain. In the highly price-sensitive German market, Marlboro's recovery is being hampered by a widening of price gaps. In Greece, consumers have been down-trading due to steep price increases and in large price gaps in a difficult economic environments.
L&M is the second best selling cigarette brand in the EU region after Marlboro. It's strong momentum continued in the third quarter. With market share growth notably in Belgium, Czech Republic, Germany, Greece, The Netherlands, Poland, Portugal and Slovakia. For the region as a whole, L&M grew 0.6 share points to 6.3%. 
Outside the EU region, Marlboro is performing very strongly, with market share gains across a wide range of different geographies. Marlboro volume increased by 9.8% in Asia, excluding Japan, was up 0.8% in the Latin America and Canada region and was down only marginally in the region. 
Let me now turn to our momentum in key markets, starting with the EU region. In the third quarter, total industry volume was down 5.5%, driven primarily by the recession-related, double-digit decline of the Spanish market. The combination of price elasticity this year and trade purchase patents last year in the Polish market and the impact of higher prices in the economic crisis in Greece. Our total market share in the EU region increased by 0.2 points in the third quarter to 39.1% behind an overall solid performance across our main markets. 
In Greece, our market share is increasing sequentially as the growth of L&M has more than offset the decline in Marlboro. To maintain the competitiveness of Marlboro, we were obliged to partially absorb tax increases that occurred earlier this year. We expect that the Greek market will continue to act as a drag on our regional profitability growth into the beginning of next year while discussions on structural changes to the excise tax system continue.
We increased our shipment volume in the very important Russian market by 1.4% in the third quarter to a record level of 25.4 billion units. This strong performance was driven by above premium parliament, mid-priced Chesterfield and low-priced Bond Street and mixed. PMI implemented price increases of two to three rubles per pack in July. The market is stabilizing overall and consumer down-trading continues to slow. 
Industry volumes during the third quarter in Ukraine is estimated to have been down about 15%, reflecting the size of trade purchases in June, ahead of the latest tax increases, and a market contraction, resulting from continuous price increases over the last two years. Our volume declined by 2.6 billion units or about one quarter. Premium Marlboro and mid-priced Chesterfield gained share, but we shed share at the low end of the markets. The improved mix and higher prices enabled us to strongly increase our profitability in Ukraine during the third quarter.
While the decline slowed in the third quarter, industry volume in Turkey was still down by about 6% year-on-year. As consumers have switched to contraband cigarettes and loose tobacco, following the very large tax-driven price increases earlier this year. Though our volume and product mix remains unfavorable compared to last year, our market share in Turkey is starting to improve sequentially, which makes us optimistic that the outlook will be better next year after a difficult 2010. 
While our shipments to Japan in the third quarter were 3.5 billion units below the prior year, sales by our distributor to the trade rose by 4 billion units or 27.3%. We estimate that the retail trade built up about 10 days of additional stock and consumers purchased some three weeks of stock ahead of the October, 2010 retail price increases. Consequently, retail sales this month have been very limited, and we will only be able to see the consumers' reaction to the higher prices towards the end of the quarter and during the first part of next year. 
Let me remind you that the retail selling price for cigarettes grew very significantly this month with a 37.5 increase for Marlboro. While the price increases are unprecedented in their magnitude and take place in a deflationary environment, cigarettes remain relatively affordable, and therefore, we are optimistic that our profitability will be enhanced going forward. 
Industry volume in Indonesia grew by a further 3.9% in the quarter, broadly in line with the annual trends. Our shipments were up 3.1% in the third quarter despite the temporarily unfavorable impact on A Mild, as the leading brand in Indonesia of costing through the 10,000 rupiah per pack price point. Our overall market share was down 0.2 points, while our profitability in Indonesia grew at a double-digit rate in the quarter, thanks to higher prices and the growing volumes.
In Korea, PMI volume increased by 9.7% in the third quarter and our market share grew by 2.4 points to 17%, thanks in particular to Marlboro and Parliament, whose growth in recent quarters in Korea has been nothing less than spectacular. Meanwhile, as elsewhere in the world, PMI continues to advocate for the adoption of a system of regular, moderate excise tax increases. 
In the Latin America and Canada region, overall industry volume in key markets was essentially stable in the quarter. The Canadian market grew by 4.2% a slower pace that reflects the fact that we have left the period last year, when the provincial authorities in Québec and Ontario started to increase their enforcement against contraband sales. The markets in Argentina and Mexico were down slightly. Our strong growth, share growth, continued in the quarter in the key markets of Argentina and Mexico. In the latter, Marlboro continued to grow share and has now captured nearly half the market, helped by the rollout of the new architecture. 
Excluding currency and acquisitions, OCI in the quarter was up 2.2%, driven by higher pricing that was partially offset by lower volumes and an unfavorable mix in Canada. The low-priced brands have become more prominent, following the decline in the illicit trade. In the fourth quarter, profitability will be enhanced by the recently announced retail price increase of half a peso in Argentina. 
Our working capital reduction program is reinforcing our tremendous cash flow generation. In the third quarter this year, our operating cash flow was 30.9% higher at $2.4 billion. Excluding currency, operating cash flow was up by 43.6%. Free cash flow increased at a slightly faster rate of 33.6% and 47.4%, excluding currency. 
On a year-to-date basis, our operating cash flow has reached $7.9 billion for a cumulative total of $23.7 billion since the beginning of 2008. With one quarter to go, we have already surpassed the $27 billion cumulative three-year operating cash flow target that we established at the spin by nearly 10%.
Our financial strength enables us to generously reward our shareholders. Thanks to the continued strong growth of our cash flow, we have increased our allocations for share repurchases for the full year to $5 billion, accelerating the rate of purchases this year under our previously approved program by $1 billion more than originally foreseen. 
In the third quarter we spent $1.1 billion to purchase an additional 20.7 million shares and have spent $3.9 billion in all so far this year to buy 78.5 million shares. In September, we increased our quarterly dividend by 10.3% to $0.64 a share, an annualized rate of $2.56. In fact, since the March 2008 spin, we have raised our dividend by 39% and our dividend yield stands at 4.5%.
So let me now summarize. By the belief, we continue to be an attractive investment opportunity. We have strong business momentum going into the fourth quarter, and we'll benefit from higher margins in Japan as well as price increases in Argentina, France, Indonesia, Italy, Poland, Portugal, Russia and the UK. We also have a more favorable currency tailwind than previously factored into our forecast and a lower tax rate. 
Consequently, we are raising and narrowing our reported diluted EPS guidance for 2010 to a range of $3.90 to $3.95. Compared to 2009, this represents a strong growth rate of approximately 20% to 22%. 
We have market leadership and are growing volume and overall share in emerging markets. Marlboro is performing well behind its new brand architecture and innovative line extensions, with overall share up in EU regions in the third quarter and either increasing or stable in our three other regions. 
Our pricing power remains strong due to our brand leadership and broad portfolio. The outlook for costs going forward is improving. Our growing cash flow has enabled us to accelerate our share repurchase program this year to a total spending target of $5 billion. And we raised our dividend by 10.3% in September, thus providing effective returns to our shareholders. Thank you. I will now be pleased to answer any questions you may have.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is coming from David Adelman with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is coming from David Adelman with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: First, with respect to pricing in the quarter, you highlighted a number of comparative issues, timing issues. You talked about the fourth quarter. But if you step back, do you feel as if there's been any moderation in your broad global capacity to raise p
componenttext: First, with respect to pricing in the quarter, you highlighted a number of comparative issues, timing issues. You talked about the fourth quarter. But if you step back, do you feel as if there's been any moderation in your broad global capacity to raise pricing either because of consumer resistance or competitive dynamics?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, I don't see a moderation there. We continue to do what we did last year and the year before. We look at every market. We take our decisions on a market-by-market basis. As you know, underlying fundamentals that would've changed.
componenttext: No, I don't see a moderation there. We continue to do what we did last year and the year before. We look at every market. We take our decisions on a market-by-market basis. As you know, underlying fundamentals that would've changed.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And secondly, Hermann, I know you're not going to discreetly comment about the outlook for next year, but would you agree there are a number of dynamics that should flatter results next year. You're going to have significant pricing in Japan, where presum
componenttext: And secondly, Hermann, I know you're not going to discreetly comment about the outlook for next year, but would you agree there are a number of dynamics that should flatter results next year. You're going to have significant pricing in Japan, where presumably profits, prior to this increase, have been on a downward trend. You have FX in your favor. You're seeing some improvements in the EM, in emerging markets. You're going to get some cost savings in the Philippines and the buyback will continue. Do you agree with those sort of -- not that there won't be negative dynamics next year, but you certainly will go into next year with those things in your favor.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, absolutely. I don't know about Forex because nobody knows about foreign exchange the way it looks now today. Yes, Japan, of course, we have tremendous margin increases in there. We all know that we have to see what the consumer reaction is. Yes, we d
componenttext: Yes, absolutely. I don't know about Forex because nobody knows about foreign exchange the way it looks now today. Yes, Japan, of course, we have tremendous margin increases in there. We all know that we have to see what the consumer reaction is. Yes, we do have a very strong position in emerging markets further reinforced of course by the business combination in the Philippines, and beyond that, of course fantastic position there. Yes, there are certainly cost synergies as well that you can find there. Overall, I would also say that we will certainly keep our cost focus and productivity focus also in the next year.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Lastly, in Japan, am I right thinking that this one-off windfall from the revaluation of inventory maybe that's $100 million or $120 million?
componenttext: Lastly, in Japan, am I right thinking that this one-off windfall from the revaluation of inventory maybe that's $100 million or $120 million?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Might be even slightly better than that.
componenttext: Might be even slightly better than that.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Although that's truly one off, correct? I mean, that's sort of a windfall. You'll be less that next year, when you look at the fourth quarter?
componenttext: Although that's truly one off, correct? I mean, that's sort of a windfall. You'll be less that next year, when you look at the fourth quarter?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, that's not a windfall. Really what it is there, this reflects the increased margins on our products. In a different situation, a different structure in the market, you won't realize those additional market margins simply as you sell your products now
componenttext: No, that's not a windfall. Really what it is there, this reflects the increased margins on our products. In a different situation, a different structure in the market, you won't realize those additional market margins simply as you sell your products now to the consumer. We have an import structure in the Japanese market, which only means that on the inventories at the distributor, you take this margin increase in one go already in the month of October, which otherwise would've come in kind of every day. So it's not at all a windfall. It is simply reflecting the increased margins in that market, going forward.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Judy Hong of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Judy Hong of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: On Japan, so all of the inventory that got built up in the second quarter, would you say that, that has been now kind of flushed out at the shipment level now, so that in fourth quarter, it really would be a reflection of what the consumer dynamic would l
componenttext: On Japan, so all of the inventory that got built up in the second quarter, would you say that, that has been now kind of flushed out at the shipment level now, so that in fourth quarter, it really would be a reflection of what the consumer dynamic would look like?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, we have inventories in the market that's kind of on the basis of middle of the road assumption we consider to be unreasonable. Now of course, we will see what's the real consumer reaction is, and you always have to adapt then inventories to y
componenttext: Yes. I mean, we have inventories in the market that's kind of on the basis of middle of the road assumption we consider to be unreasonable. Now of course, we will see what's the real consumer reaction is, and you always have to adapt then inventories to your prospective sales. But I believe that we're on a very reasonable basis there, which is baked into our full year guidance.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just staying on Japan, in terms of -- going back to David's question. So you have the margin improvement from the higher pricing that you've taken, but you also have the favorable revaluation of I think, about $32 million that should benefit you in the fo
componenttext: Just staying on Japan, in terms of -- going back to David's question. So you have the margin improvement from the higher pricing that you've taken, but you also have the favorable revaluation of I think, about $32 million that should benefit you in the fourth quarter?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: No. The secret in Japan has simply been that if I go quarter by quarter, you have the inventory buildup in the second. You have to pay back for that in the third. There is no tax windfall in the market in Japan that is taken by the government. Every produ
componenttext: No. The secret in Japan has simply been that if I go quarter by quarter, you have the inventory buildup in the second. You have to pay back for that in the third. There is no tax windfall in the market in Japan that is taken by the government. Every product sold as of October 1, the new tax has to be paid and gets to the government. So what's coming in now is really the additional margin on the stock at the distributor which we have. That additional margin that is made on the inventories at the retailer stays with the retailer. That's the only thing there.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just kind of taking a step back and looking at your operating profit in the third quarter. Obviously, a lot of negative impact from Japan and so forth. But if you adjust for Japan and the tax absorption in Greece, are you able to quantify how much adjuste
componenttext: Just kind of taking a step back and looking at your operating profit in the third quarter. Obviously, a lot of negative impact from Japan and so forth. But if you adjust for Japan and the tax absorption in Greece, are you able to quantify how much adjusted operating income ex currency and ex acquisition would have been in the third quarter?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: There's two ways of looking at that. I mean, the first one, adjusted growth rates. So, let's put it this way. Japan alone is about a four percentage points drag in PMI's results in the quarter, and Greece and Turkey together would add another two percenta
componenttext: There's two ways of looking at that. I mean, the first one, adjusted growth rates. So, let's put it this way. Japan alone is about a four percentage points drag in PMI's results in the quarter, and Greece and Turkey together would add another two percentage points. But actually, maybe an even better way to answer your question is really to look at OCI margins, because in the third quarter, the overall PMI ex currency and acquisition is negative. There are so many distortions in there that I would rather say why don't you look at September year-to-date. There are only, actually, Asia, then would still show a negative OCI ex currency development of minus 2.9%. In Asia then, you have two things in there which is of course, first, the Philippines, which is what I call a welcome dilution effect of the margin, because the Philippines is of course, a new basis for future growth. So if you then take that one out, then Asia ex currency and ex acquisition would be down minus 1.3 and would be the only region that you have negative OCI margin developments. Well, now as we were just talking, we found new margins based on revaluation effect in the fourth quarter. Also Asia is going to turn positive by year end, and all four regions, in my opinion, will show positive OCI margin increases even excluding currency and acquisitions. So that is another way of looking at it and is another way of demonstrating that the fundamentals are in very good shape.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of your share buyback comment, as you continue to deliver on the cash flow figures that actually are pretty robust, would you commit to -- you got this $12 billion of share buyback that's over three year period, but if the cash flow does come in
componenttext: In terms of your share buyback comment, as you continue to deliver on the cash flow figures that actually are pretty robust, would you commit to -- you got this $12 billion of share buyback that's over three year period, but if the cash flow does come in better than expected, would you be open to accelerating the buyback beyond what you are doing in 2010?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: We have made a decision for 2010 to accelerate by $1 billion and to bring it to a $5 billion total for this year. We will take the decision for next year, then at the beginning of next year. I would say, I'll ask your patience, let's talk about next year,
componenttext: We have made a decision for 2010 to accelerate by $1 billion and to bring it to a $5 billion total for this year. We will take the decision for next year, then at the beginning of next year. I would say, I'll ask your patience, let's talk about next year, when we're in next year.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Adam Spielman of Citigroup.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Adam Spielman of Citigroup.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: You talked about the tax rate's going down. Can you give some guidance about what the ongoing tax rate is likely to be?
componenttext: You talked about the tax rate's going down. Can you give some guidance about what the ongoing tax rate is likely to be?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: The ongoing tax rate is in the range of 29% as it was before. Actually for this year end, if you take the midpoint actually of our guidance increase, and this is $0.125, $0.02 were actually for the tax rate reasons, and $0.08 were for currency and anythin
componenttext: The ongoing tax rate is in the range of 29% as it was before. Actually for this year end, if you take the midpoint actually of our guidance increase, and this is $0.125, $0.02 were actually for the tax rate reasons, and $0.08 were for currency and anything between $0.02 and $0.03 were for improved business outlook.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm sorry I missed that. Is 29% is the ongoing tax rate?
componenttext: I'm sorry I missed that. Is 29% is the ongoing tax rate?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Correct, yes.
componenttext: Correct, yes.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Of that $0.02 or $0.03 increase you just mentioned, just a second ago, geographically, can you sort of say where you've got more optimistic?
componenttext: Of that $0.02 or $0.03 increase you just mentioned, just a second ago, geographically, can you sort of say where you've got more optimistic?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's not more optimistic, it is back to business. It is good pricing in many places around the world. I have been quoting many of them for the fourth quarter, by the way we will benefit from those also going into the new year. And also, a pretty good comp
componenttext: It's not more optimistic, it is back to business. It is good pricing in many places around the world. I have been quoting many of them for the fourth quarter, by the way we will benefit from those also going into the new year. And also, a pretty good competitive position in many places around the world. So those two together are the basis for the increase on the business.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: If I summarize that, that sounds like it's the price increases recently announced. Is that fair enough to boil it down to a single point?
componenttext: If I summarize that, that sounds like it's the price increases recently announced. Is that fair enough to boil it down to a single point?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: No. Actually, I was just quoting two reasons. It's the price increases on one hand, but it's also the improved competitive position. You heard me in the prepared remarks our shared performances including Marlboro over many places in the world. It's the co
componenttext: No. Actually, I was just quoting two reasons. It's the price increases on one hand, but it's also the improved competitive position. You heard me in the prepared remarks our shared performances including Marlboro over many places in the world. It's the combination of the two.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: If I look at your pricing variance over time, there's obviously, you got some very tough comps, but at the beginning of this year -- in the quarters towards the end of last year, it was either $500 million, and in the fourth quarter it was almost $500 mil
componenttext: If I look at your pricing variance over time, there's obviously, you got some very tough comps, but at the beginning of this year -- in the quarters towards the end of last year, it was either $500 million, and in the fourth quarter it was almost $500 million. This year it's been consistently below that, $340 million in the first couple of quarters and now $292 million. If you exclude Japan, which is a bit of a one-off, do you think the pricing variance we've had so far this year is a reasonable number to be thinking about going forward? Or do you think 2009 is a better base?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well if you go back one more year, then 2008 was roughly a pricing variance of $1.2 billion. 2009 was actually $2 billion. 2010, we are kind of somewhere in the middle of the two. I would not call it all Japan a one-off. There was probably not going to be
componenttext: Well if you go back one more year, then 2008 was roughly a pricing variance of $1.2 billion. 2009 was actually $2 billion. 2010, we are kind of somewhere in the middle of the two. I would not call it all Japan a one-off. There was probably not going to be a price increase in Japan next year. However, it is always a mixture around the world. And there is a mixture of markets, there is also a mixture of timing, and that's what I was alluding to. Okay, the third quarter was a relatively moderate quarter in that sense, but it doesn't mean anything on the fundamentals as you see that this year, the fourth quarter happens to be a strong quarter.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our Next question comes from Christine Farkas of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our Next question comes from Christine Farkas of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
