headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Did I hear you correctly that you've applied for or planned to implement price increases in Poland and Ukraine in the fourth quarter?
componenttext: Did I hear you correctly that you've applied for or planned to implement price increases in Poland and Ukraine in the fourth quarter?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, not in the Ukraine. In the Ukraine prices have just gone up. There was a price increase, tax increase July 1, that was about all product for one and a half months in the market. Now since mid-August, I would say the consumer has seen the new price. Ye
componenttext: No, not in the Ukraine. In the Ukraine prices have just gone up. There was a price increase, tax increase July 1, that was about all product for one and a half months in the market. Now since mid-August, I would say the consumer has seen the new price. Yes, we are in the process of implementing a price increase in Poland. That's right. The government there has decided for a tax increase of about 4% as of January. The price increases, however, will come before, and we have applied with customs authorities in Portugal.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Now, Poland has been tough we saw a tough third quarter with further price hikes. Do you see these levels as reasonable, or do you expect more shock to the volumes there?
componenttext: Now, Poland has been tough we saw a tough third quarter with further price hikes. Do you see these levels as reasonable, or do you expect more shock to the volumes there?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, I mean, the volume compare is just a bit distorted in the Polish market. You had that situation there, remember, the year-on-year packed tobacco taxation change. And then you have a lot flowing back into the cigarette markets, so comps are a bit diffi
componenttext: No, I mean, the volume compare is just a bit distorted in the Polish market. You had that situation there, remember, the year-on-year packed tobacco taxation change. And then you have a lot flowing back into the cigarette markets, so comps are a bit difficult there. No, we are pretty happy about the Polish market. We are growing share. We are performing well. Marlboro is growing in the markets. I don't see an underlying problem there.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And just rounding out the EU, if I look at historical numbers correctly, it looks like you won share in the EU for the first time in about seven quarters or longer. I just want to understand because your volumes are still a bit tough in couple of countrie
componenttext: And just rounding out the EU, if I look at historical numbers correctly, it looks like you won share in the EU for the first time in about seven quarters or longer. I just want to understand because your volumes are still a bit tough in couple of countries, but we did see Marlboro win share in some regions as well. I'm wondering if you think this is now a turn, or if there's something structural in the quarter that allowed you to win share optically, but likely could still be challenged there on the trade down basis.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I really think what we see are initiatives on the new Marlboro architecture on innovation about Marlboro, that this is really bearing fruit around the world, we'll part limited to Europe. And there are of course -- and in addition to that, there are alway
componenttext: I really think what we see are initiatives on the new Marlboro architecture on innovation about Marlboro, that this is really bearing fruit around the world, we'll part limited to Europe. And there are of course -- and in addition to that, there are always some more difficult countries in Europe. That would be Germany, where Marlboro still is held back but there is more or less -- the reason for that is increased price gaps because of rebates given on big and what they call maxi packs, that's packs of 30 cigarettes, or 28, 29. So that's more of a price gap issue, but if you take it all together, really, many other markets in Europe where we are doing well. That's for Marlboro. For the overall share. We should never forget that we always have, with L&M, also the number two brand in the EU region. So we are very, very strongly positioned with the number one and the number two at the top end and at the low-end of the markets.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: On Pakistan, your press release indicated growth. I just wanted to understand if there was organic growth there, given the floods and the impact on distribution in the quarter.
componenttext: On Pakistan, your press release indicated growth. I just wanted to understand if there was organic growth there, given the floods and the impact on distribution in the quarter.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of consumer uptake, that's very hard to say what the situation there in Pakistan is. And then, these floods as we all know covered in the area as big as Italy. When it comes to shipments in our case, those shipments are actually up, but it is a l
componenttext: In terms of consumer uptake, that's very hard to say what the situation there in Pakistan is. And then, these floods as we all know covered in the area as big as Italy. When it comes to shipments in our case, those shipments are actually up, but it is a load and deload thing. We have some trade notes in this quarter, Q3 2010, heard of rumors of price increases. There is in Q3 2009, there was actually a deload in the market, because there had occurred a price increase in June, 2009. So it's easy comps in a sense, therefore our shipments are up in Pakistan. The one thing that concerns me a bit more in Pakistan is that we see the non-tax paid segment, let me call it, which now is approaching 20% of consumption in the market.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Finally, Hermann, on your guidance, you gave us a breakdown of the $0.125. You also boosted the buy back plans in the quarter. Do you not see that as having an impact on your earnings in the fourth quarter, or is that built in the $0.02 to $0.03 business
componenttext: Finally, Hermann, on your guidance, you gave us a breakdown of the $0.125. You also boosted the buy back plans in the quarter. Do you not see that as having an impact on your earnings in the fourth quarter, or is that built in the $0.02 to $0.03 business outlook?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, no, no, the additional share buybacks in the fourth quarter only have minimal effect on the EPS growth of this year. So the divisor, if you like, when you go for EPS per share is essentially a daily weighted average, i.e., the share repurchases at the
componenttext: No, no, no, the additional share buybacks in the fourth quarter only have minimal effect on the EPS growth of this year. So the divisor, if you like, when you go for EPS per share is essentially a daily weighted average, i.e., the share repurchases at the end of the year have very little impact on your EPS rates of the year, however then, you kind of actually imagine that the comps are put back to zero on January 1 of the subsequent year, so you do get the full benefit than actually the year thereafter we allocate in 2011. But no meaningful impact actually on EPS growth rate of this year. The $0.025, $0.02 to $0.03 that I was quoting is real underlying business.,

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ann Gurkin of Davenport.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ann Gurkin of Davenport.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can I just get an update on the fine-cut tobacco market and your strategy for that market?
componenttext: Can I just get an update on the fine-cut tobacco market and your strategy for that market?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Fine-cut tobacco market essentially in the international arena, the most important part of it is in Europe. We are doing well in there. You know that we had a couple of tack-on acquisitions of some brands there. We are doing alright. We keep on going. On
componenttext: Fine-cut tobacco market essentially in the international arena, the most important part of it is in Europe. We are doing well in there. You know that we had a couple of tack-on acquisitions of some brands there. We are doing alright. We keep on going. On the other hand, the focus certainly always should be cigarettes, because the margins are higher in cigarettes. And very often, this is a question of taxation of roll your own, make your own, let's remember that's why you had a steep increase a year ago in Spain until the fixation there was corrected. Since then, things are back to normal. Yes, we are an active player in the market and things are going okay, I would say.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: With respect to the potential adoption of the use of LIP paper? Have you all made any decisions when you would adopt the use of LIP? When you think that requirement will be put through in the EU markets, and who you might use as your supplier?
componenttext: With respect to the potential adoption of the use of LIP paper? Have you all made any decisions when you would adopt the use of LIP? When you think that requirement will be put through in the EU markets, and who you might use as your supplier?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think the best estimates for now is that the EU commission will come out with defined standards towards the end of 2011, towards the end of next year. Implementation probably in the year 2012. We are of course in discussion with several suppliers of wha
componenttext: I think the best estimates for now is that the EU commission will come out with defined standards towards the end of 2011, towards the end of next year. Implementation probably in the year 2012. We are of course in discussion with several suppliers of what the cost of such different paper would be on an industrial scale. As you know, there are several techniques that can be used to achieve the desired result and these discussions are going on with various suppliers. You will understand that I would rather refrain from giving a cost estimate. Let's wait for the outcome of those discussions and negotiations.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Is it fair to say you will probably wait to adopt the use of LIP until the middle of next year 2011, or can you comment on that?
componenttext: Is it fair to say you will probably wait to adopt the use of LIP until the middle of next year 2011, or can you comment on that?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: We will adopt it when the legal requirement is there. I see no reason to do it earlier.
componenttext: We will adopt it when the legal requirement is there. I see no reason to do it earlier.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from John Leinster with UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from John Leinster with UBS.

componenttext: First of all, just follow-up on Japan, what is the average stock in terms of weeks or months for days held by the distribution in Japan?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: That is a little bit too much of a detail that I probably don't want to go to. I mean, you have to take into account that we have a long pipeline, because the product is coming from our European factories. We always adapt it to our prospective sales, but
componenttext: That is a little bit too much of a detail that I probably don't want to go to. I mean, you have to take into account that we have a long pipeline, because the product is coming from our European factories. We always adapt it to our prospective sales, but to go into the detailed inventory number. I'm afraid I wouldn't want to do that.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And certainly in Germany, the market share loss, is that going to other branded players or does that represent the growth of the retail brands?
componenttext: And certainly in Germany, the market share loss, is that going to other branded players or does that represent the growth of the retail brands?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, rate trends are actually not growing much. They are stable at around 12% to 13% in the market. Our market share situation, and in particular the market share situation of Marlboro is driven by increased price gaps in that market. Remember, a year ago
componenttext: No, rate trends are actually not growing much. They are stable at around 12% to 13% in the market. Our market share situation, and in particular the market share situation of Marlboro is driven by increased price gaps in that market. Remember, a year ago or so we had those price skirmishes around soft packs that has disappeared. Now we have a price skirmishes in rebates for big and bigger packs, 25s up to 30s packs. There are rebates now in the market for packs if you would reconvert that to 19s packs that go up to $0.23 per pack. So that's the competitive situation there. We, of course, had to follow, and we have just launched by the way a Marlboro Maxi Pack EUR 6.90 for 29s there. So that's a bit the situation in Germany. It's not about the trade brands. It is about industry, competitors bringing tax with the rebate as the justification of their size.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: In Spain, it seems slightly counterintuitive given the problems of the Spanish market and the Spanish economy in general, that Marlboro should be growing. I mean, is that just the reversal of what's going on in Germany, just the price gap should close or
componenttext: In Spain, it seems slightly counterintuitive given the problems of the Spanish market and the Spanish economy in general, that Marlboro should be growing. I mean, is that just the reversal of what's going on in Germany, just the price gap should close or is there something else going on within the Spanish market?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, in all fairness, I have to say that the Marlboro share during the summer period, when the tourists are coming into Spain is always higher, so there is a benefit on Marlboro on that clearly. However, we have somebody searching some preliminary evidence
componenttext: No, in all fairness, I have to say that the Marlboro share during the summer period, when the tourists are coming into Spain is always higher, so there is a benefit on Marlboro on that clearly. However, we have somebody searching some preliminary evidence that it was not only the foreign tourists that were smoking more Marlboros than before, it was also localized Spanish tourists during the holiday period. I think that August will, for the future, once the economy in Spain will recover. And it is just another proof of really of the vibrancy of the Marlboro brand in that market and good prospects going forward.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our Next question comes from Roger Fujimori of Credit Suisse.
componenttext: Our Next question comes from Roger Fujimori of Credit Suisse.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: On Mexico, if you could give us an update on the outlook for cigarette taxation given the current discussions in Congress?
componenttext: On Mexico, if you could give us an update on the outlook for cigarette taxation given the current discussions in Congress?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's correct that the lower house yesterday voted for an increase of specific tax, not on the low end, that was unchanged. From a previously foreseen amount of MXN 1.20 per pack to MXN 7. The legislative process is still ongoing. The Senate vote in that p
componenttext: It's correct that the lower house yesterday voted for an increase of specific tax, not on the low end, that was unchanged. From a previously foreseen amount of MXN 1.20 per pack to MXN 7. The legislative process is still ongoing. The Senate vote in that process is outstanding. The key question, I believe, is can and will those MXN 7 per pack be split over a period over several years, which I think would make imminent sense.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from David Hayes of Nomura.
componenttext: Our next question comes from David Hayes of Nomura.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: On Turkey, looks like sequentially, turkey's getting a little bit easier in terms of volumes. Is that just the consumer getting used to the new price points from January, or is there anything else going on there that means that those volumes seems to be s
componenttext: On Turkey, looks like sequentially, turkey's getting a little bit easier in terms of volumes. Is that just the consumer getting used to the new price points from January, or is there anything else going on there that means that those volumes seems to be stabilizing a little bit? And then just in terms of Russia, played [ph] by the trends again, just through the quarter, whether you can talk about whether those trends are getting better through the period, whether there's any negative impacts? Obviously, there were fires and heat waves, that disrupted during the period in Russia. And then just also -- whether there's an update on what's going on with tax increases moving forward. I know there's meant to be good visibility on that, but there seems to be news [indiscernible] (55:36) coming out that, that may change slightly. So I wonder what your position is on that tax risk in Russia moving forward.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Turkey, take it as a country first, the macros are really excellent. GDP is up 10%, purchasing power is up. Unemployment is down. Inflation is at fairly low levels for Turkish standards, 6.5% [ph] (56:04). So consumer confidence is up, all there together,
componenttext: Turkey, take it as a country first, the macros are really excellent. GDP is up 10%, purchasing power is up. Unemployment is down. Inflation is at fairly low levels for Turkish standards, 6.5% [ph] (56:04). So consumer confidence is up, all there together, I think, we see that consumers have adjusted a little bit to the prices. That being said, prices are extremely high and we see negative mix in that market, because price gaps are also high. I believe that's about the story about Turkey. Moving over to Russia, there are two things here. I mean, really the down trading which we see phasing out, I mean there are clear and hard numbers here. If I look at our distributor sales then premium sales in Q3. Premium is down minus 3.5%. In Q1, this was down 12.2%, you can see a huge improvement. Mid down 6.3% in Q3 versus 11% in Q1 and low increasing 8% versus 11% in Q1. Our brands, same thing. Q3, Parliament, up 2.7%; Chesterfield, 6.7% up; Bond Street, 20% up; and Optima, 1% up. So you clearly can see down-trading is phasing out in that market. When it comes to excise tax, while the present proposal has gone through the first reading at the Dumark [ph] (57:40) that proposal means roughly a rollover need of RUB 3 per pack. So that's an increase above inflation, but I wouldn't call it disruptive. The legislative process, however, is not yet over. But for now things look reasonable.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from [indiscernible] Gupta [ph] (58:12) with Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Our next question comes from [indiscernible] Gupta [ph] (58:12) with Barclays Capital.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think I can actually answer both questions at the same time, because, they, of course, go together. I mean, at the end of the day, the way we look at that is we look at our projections of our operating cash flow. From there, we would look at our capital
componenttext: I think I can actually answer both questions at the same time, because, they, of course, go together. I mean, at the end of the day, the way we look at that is we look at our projections of our operating cash flow. From there, we would look at our capital expenditure requirements we have, mid and long term over multi-year average would be that it should about equal at max depreciation and amortization, then you would look at your multi-year average of what you might need for tack-on acquisitions, take a multiyear average of $1 billion or so for the tack-ons. Then you would kind of put the framework around that our credit rating are A credit rating gives us. We like our credit-rating. We want to keep that credit rating, because it gives us all the flexibility in the world. So within those ratings, then you get to your dividends. Our dividend payout ratio is 65%. You know that. You also have seen our last dividend increase in there. And from there, you get to the share repurchases, which kind of is the remainder of that whole calculation.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our final question comes from Adam Spielman of Citigroup.
componenttext: Our final question comes from Adam Spielman of Citigroup.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: One is Australia, you had a big tax rise. Are you able to say briefly, what happened to volumes and what happened to profits in that market? And secondly, on pricing, if you look at your emerging markets, would you say that typically your pricing is above
componenttext: One is Australia, you had a big tax rise. Are you able to say briefly, what happened to volumes and what happened to profits in that market? And secondly, on pricing, if you look at your emerging markets, would you say that typically your pricing is above inflation in those markets, and if so, sort of roughly how much? In very broad terms, how should I think about it?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: So let's go first to Australia. The total market decline is moderating in Australia. It is down about 14% since the April tax increase, but more recently, we've seen about 6% decline, so it is moderating. When it comes to profitability, we have solid sing
componenttext: So let's go first to Australia. The total market decline is moderating in Australia. It is down about 14% since the April tax increase, but more recently, we've seen about 6% decline, so it is moderating. When it comes to profitability, we have solid single digit OCI growth in that markets, so is there is real increase in profitability still and Australia. So from that sense, it's good. By the way, there is no really new news in packaging in that market. The government is now studying the situation, and we remain confident that they will recognize and then eventually exposure and finally listen to the common sense arguments there that the combination of high prices, product display ban and plain packaging will do nothing else but facilitate illicit business of criminals. So much on Australia. Then on more general pricing question. It always is a situation that we really take on a market-by-market basis. Our price increases in Russia would have been clearly above inflation. In Indonesia, it would've been slightly above inflation. So it is, like always, there is really no general answer. I can't give a generalized answer. It is on a market-by-market basis depending on what is the competitive situation, what is the purchasing power, what are the unemployment trends in the market, what else is happening, what is the consumer confidence level in the markets. So these are all elements that go into it. So I only can give you examples for the past four key markets like Indonesia and Russia.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's was our final question. I'll now turn the floor back over to Nick Rolli for any closing remarks.
componenttext: That's was our final question. I'll now turn the floor back over to Nick Rolli for any closing remarks.
